Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|Get Help
indexed_text: There are a number of ways to learn more about your product and interact with Oracle and other users.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|Get Help|Get Help in the Applications
indexed_text: Some application pages have help icons

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|Get Help|Get Help in the Applications
indexed_text: to give you access to contextual help. If you don't see any help icons on your page, click your user image or name in the global header and select Show Help Icons. If the page has contextual help, help icons will appear.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|Get Help|Get Support
indexed_text: You can get support at My Oracle Support . For accessible support, visit Oracle Accessibility Learning and Support .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|Get Help|Get Training
indexed_text: Increase your knowledge of Oracle Cloud by taking courses at Oracle University .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|Get Help|Join Our Community
indexed_text: Use Cloud Customer Connect to get information from industry experts at Oracle and in the partner community. You can join forums to connect with other customers, post questions, suggest ideas for product enhancements, and watch events.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|Get Help|Learn About Accessibility
indexed_text: For information about Oracle's commitment to accessibility, visit the Oracle Accessibility Program . Videos included in this guide are provided as a media alternative for text-based topics also available in this guide.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|Get Help|Share Your Feedback
indexed_text: We welcome your feedback about Oracle Applications user assistance. If you need clarification, find an error, or just want to tell us what you found helpful, we'd like to hear from you.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|Get Help|Share Your Feedback
indexed_text: You can email your feedback to oracle_fusion_applications_help_ww_grp@oracle.com .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|Get Help|Share Your Feedback
indexed_text: Thanks for helping us improve our user assistance!

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud
indexed_text: Overview of Define Oracle Fusion Accounting Hub Configuration for Rapid Implementation

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud
indexed_text: Use the Define Oracle Fusion Accounting Hub Configuration for Rapid Implementation task list to streamline your setup configurations. The rapid implementation task list minimizes the time used to complete your key configurations and enables the day-to-day use of Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud applications.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud
indexed_text: The rapid implementation task list includes tasks that are:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud
indexed_text: Critical setup tasks.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud
indexed_text: Setup steps that are required by most users.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud
indexed_text: To create an implementation project that includes the Define Accounting Entry Configuration for Rapid Implementation task list, use the Manage Implementation Projects page in the Setup and Maintenance work area. You can modify the task list as needed and assign and track each task.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud
indexed_text: Note: You are not restricted to only the setup configuration in the rapid implementation task list. You can manually add the standard Oracle Fusion Accounting Hub offering task lists and tasks to your rapid implementation project.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Creating the Implementation Project To create an implementation project, follow these steps:
indexed_text: 1. From the Setup and Maintenance work area, open the Setup page. You must have the Manage Implementation Project ( ASM_MANAGE_IMPLEMENTATION_PROJECT_PRIV) privilege. 2. From the Setup page, open the panel drawer and select Manage Implementation Projects . 3. Click the Create icon. 4. Enter a meaningful name and a brief description to describe your project. 5. Optionally, assign the project to a user and specify a start date. 6. Click Save and Open Project when you complete your selection. 7. You can begin to assign the tasks to the appropriate users. Select and add the Define Fusion Accounting Hub Configuration for Rapid Implementation task list.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Creating the Implementation Project To create an implementation project, follow these steps:
indexed_text: Overview of Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Features

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Creating the Implementation Project To create an implementation project, follow these steps:
indexed_text: Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud provides a complete set of accounting tools and unparalleled access to financial data, including:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Creating the Implementation Project To create an implementation project, follow these steps:
indexed_text: Oracle General Ledger features that provide:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Creating the Implementation Project To create an implementation project, follow these steps:|Journal entry import and creation Real time balances from a balances cube Accounting controls Close functionality Cross-ledger intercompany balancing Calculation Manager for the definition of allocation rules using complex formulas Automatic generation of allocation journals Enhanced journal approval Year-end process management
indexed_text: Oracle Financial Reporting that provides:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Creating the Implementation Project To create an implementation project, follow these steps:|Embedded balances cube functionality Multidimensional, online analytical processing of financial information Ability to slice and dice data across dimensions Drill up, down, and across on any parent level within the chart of accounts
indexed_text: Accounting transformation enables you to create subledger accounting rules that provide flexible transformation of transaction and reference information from diverse, non-Oracle, industry applications into accurate, detailed, auditable accounting entries. The subledger accounting journals generated for non-Oracle applications are stored in a subledger accounting repository that is shared with the subledger accounting journals generated by Oracle Fusion Subledger Accounting for the subledgers such as Payables, Receivables, Assets and Inventory.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Creating the Implementation Project To create an implementation project, follow these steps:|Embedded balances cube functionality Multidimensional, online analytical processing of financial information Ability to slice and dice data across dimensions Drill up, down, and across on any parent level within the chart of accounts
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Creating the Implementation Project To create an implementation project, follow these steps:|Embedded balances cube functionality Multidimensional, online analytical processing of financial information Ability to slice and dice data across dimensions Drill up, down, and across on any parent level within the chart of accounts
indexed_text: How Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Works

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Creating the Implementation Project To create an implementation project, follow these steps:|Embedded balances cube functionality Multidimensional, online analytical processing of financial information Ability to slice and dice data across dimensions Drill up, down, and across on any parent level within the chart of accounts
indexed_text: How Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Works

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Creating the Implementation Project To create an implementation project, follow these steps:|Embedded balances cube functionality Multidimensional, online analytical processing of financial information Ability to slice and dice data across dimensions Drill up, down, and across on any parent level within the chart of accounts
indexed_text: The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud process begins by using financial data from any or all of the following:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Creating the Implementation Project To create an implementation project, follow these steps:|Embedded balances cube functionality Multidimensional, online analytical processing of financial information Ability to slice and dice data across dimensions Drill up, down, and across on any parent level within the chart of accounts
indexed_text: Non-Oracle source systems including transaction and reference information from industry-specific applications.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Creating the Implementation Project To create an implementation project, follow these steps:|Embedded balances cube functionality Multidimensional, online analytical processing of financial information Ability to slice and dice data across dimensions Drill up, down, and across on any parent level within the chart of accounts
indexed_text: Oracle Fusion subledgers including subledger journals.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Creating the Implementation Project To create an implementation project, follow these steps:|Embedded balances cube functionality Multidimensional, online analytical processing of financial information Ability to slice and dice data across dimensions Drill up, down, and across on any parent level within the chart of accounts
indexed_text: Oracle E-Business Suite, Oracle PeopleSoft, and Oracle JD Edwards general ledgers including account balances.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Creating the Implementation Project To create an implementation project, follow these steps:|Embedded balances cube functionality Multidimensional, online analytical processing of financial information Ability to slice and dice data across dimensions Drill up, down, and across on any parent level within the chart of accounts
indexed_text: The Accounting Hub process ends with complete reporting and analysis solutions.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Components
indexed_text: The Accounting Hub contains the following components:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Components
indexed_text: Accounting transformation to transform external source data.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Components
indexed_text: Oracle General Ledger to enter and post journals including allocations.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Components
indexed_text: Oracle Financial Reporting Center for reporting and analysis.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Components
indexed_text: Integration with Oracle Planning and Budgeting Cloud and Oracle Financial Consolidation and Close Cloud.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Components
indexed_text: This figure illustrates the Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud components.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud for External Source Systems
indexed_text: Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud enables you to perform accounting transformations on external, non-Oracle source system data. It utilizes the same subledger accounting rules engine that is also used to flexibly create accounting for Oracle subledgers such as Payables and Receivables. Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud includes:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud for External Source Systems
indexed_text: Registration of your external source systems, indicating what types of transactions or activities require accounting from those source systems.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud for External Source Systems
indexed_text: Create a library of transaction and reference information that is used for defining accounting treatments.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud for External Source Systems
indexed_text: Configurable accounting rules to define accounting treatments for transactions.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud for External Source Systems
indexed_text: Accounting rules engine that combines transaction and reference information from source systems with accounting rules to create detailed journals stored in an accounting repository.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud for External Source Systems
indexed_text: Detailed subledger accounting journal entry repository to enable audit and accounting reconciliation of balances.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud for External Source Systems
indexed_text: Reports and user interface inquiries for analyzing accounting transformations.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud for External Source Systems
indexed_text: Configurable analytical balances based upon source system or reference attributes.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle General Ledger
indexed_text: The Oracle General Ledger combines traditional general ledger functionality with embedded Oracle Hyperion Essbase functionality. The general ledger functionality includes:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle General Ledger
indexed_text: Journal entry creation, including updating of account balances cubes and tables.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle General Ledger
indexed_text: Date effective trees for chart of accounts maintenance and financial reporting, including What If analysis.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle General Ledger
indexed_text: Automatic balances cube creation from the chart of accounts configuration, simplifying implementation.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle General Ledger
indexed_text: Preaggregated balances at every summarization level across each dimension of the chart of accounts and accounting periods to improve reporting performance.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle General Ledger
indexed_text: Multidimensional analysis using dimensions, such as the chart of accounts, periods, and currency, to provide drill down and drill through functionally.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle General Ledger
indexed_text: Drill to details and source ledger balances from summary balances.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle General Ledger
indexed_text: Intelligence and analytics embedded within the context of a journal entry, enabling quick and accurate completion of the journal entry process. As journal entries are entered, a What If analysis to determine the impact of the unposted journals on account balances is displayed in the user interface. The What If analysis eliminates navigating to an inquiry page or running a report to verify the results.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle General Ledger
indexed_text: Three balancing segments available in your chart of accounts for more detailed reporting.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle General Ledger
indexed_text: Automatic intercompany balancing journal creation in both Subledger Accounting and General Ledger applications, ensuring proper recording of transactions across legal entities.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Oracle General Ledger
indexed_text: Calculation Manager rules using complex formulas to distribute revenue and costs throughout the organization for consistent periodic generation of allocation journal entries.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: The Oracle General Ledger provides a Financial Reporting Center with robust financial reporting and analysis using data from your balances cubes. The dimensions contained in your chart of account segments become the direct source of multidimensional analysis. Direct links are maintained to your transactional data permitting comprehensive drill-down from journals to transaction details. Use the following tools for your reporting and analysis:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: Financial Reporting to generate your reports.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: Smart View to generate spreadsheet reports.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: Oracle Transaction Business Intelligence to report using embedded analytics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: General Accounting and Journals dashboards to perform online inquiry and dashboard publication

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: Account Monitor and Account Inspector to perform online multidimensional analysis of accounting balances

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: Accounting Hub fits into Oracle's broader enterprise performance management framework through integration with Oracle Planning and Budgeting Cloud and Oracle Financial Consolidation and Close Cloud. You can you can write

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: budget from Planning and Budgeting Cloud to General Ledger or write the actual data from General Ledger to Planning and Budgeting Cloud. You can use the regular interface to load data from ERP to Financial Consolidation and Close Cloud.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: Overview of Accounting Configuration Offerings

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: Use the Setup and Maintenance work area in Oracle Applications to manage the configuration of legal entities, ledgers, and reporting currencies. To create a legal entity or ledger, first create an implementation project.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: This implementation project can be populated by either adding a financials-related offering or one or more task lists.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: Note: Setup tasks that are not related to the ledger or legal entity setup tasks are opened from either an implementation project or directly from the Setup and Maintenance work area.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: The financial applications have two predefined implementations:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud offering is used to add the General Ledger and Subledger Accounting application features to an existing Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) source system to enhance reporting and analysis.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: The Financials offering includes the General Ledger and Subledger Accounting application features and one or more subledger financial applications.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: When adding an offering to an implementation project, update the tasks displayed by adding additional tasks.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: Overview of Implementation Options for Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud has two possible implementation scenarios that can be used separately or in conjunction with each other. These scenarios are:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: Accounting for diverse business system events and transactions with configurable and auditable rule-based accounting transformations.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: Expansion of financial reporting enabling creation of multidimensional, self-service reporting and analytics with real-time accounting information from a single source with flexible formatting options.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financial Reporting Center
indexed_text: This figure illustrates Accounting Hub implementation scenarios.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Accounting for Diverse Transactions
indexed_text: The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud provides accounting for diverse business system events and transactions using configurable and auditable rule-based accounting transformations. The Accounting Hub process:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Accounting for Diverse Transactions
indexed_text: Begins with transactions and data from your non-Oracle, industry-specific subledgers and other general ledgers.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Accounting for Diverse Transactions
indexed_text: Generates accounting events using the Create Accounting process to create journals that can be posted to the Oracle General Ledger from specific subledgers and other general ledgers.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Accounting for Diverse Transactions
indexed_text: Ends with complete reporting and analysis solutions.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Accounting for Diverse Transactions
indexed_text: See the following for details on implementing this scenario: Define Accounting Transformation chapter in the Oracle Financials Cloud Implementing Accounting Hub guide.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Expansion of Financial Reporting
indexed_text: Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud enables creation of multidimensional, self-service reporting and analytics with real time accounting information from a single source with flexible formatting options. The Financial Reporting Center includes:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Expansion of Financial Reporting
indexed_text: Predefined financial reports

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Expansion of Financial Reporting
indexed_text: Ability to create reports,

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Expansion of Financial Reporting
indexed_text: Flexible options for dissemination of such reports

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Expansion of Financial Reporting
indexed_text: Account Monitor and Account Inspector providing drill-down and pivot views of your balances

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Expansion of Financial Reporting
indexed_text: Oracle Hyperion Smart View providing spreadsheet analytics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Expansion of Financial Reporting
indexed_text: Oracle Transaction Business Intelligence Oracle Business Intelligence Publisher provide key performance indicators (KPI), dashboards, and flexible reporting

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Expansion of Financial Reporting
indexed_text: For more information refer to the Using EPM with Oracle Financials Cloud link on the Books for Oracle Financials Cloud page of the Oracle Help Center at https://docs.oracle.com.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Setup Tasks Performed After Import
indexed_text: 1. Navigator > General Accounting: Financial Reporting Center > select link: Open Workspace for Financial Reports. 2. Navigate to Application > BI Catalog. 3. Navigate to File > Import. 4. Select the file you had saved during the export. If you import the folder structure, the entire structure from the source instance is imported into the existing structure on the target instance. This could result in some redundant folders. In this case, you can reorganize child folders in the structure on the target instance and delete any unneeded folders.

indexed_text: Overview of Implementing Financials

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Setup Tasks Performed After Import
indexed_text: To start your Financials implementation, use the Setup and Maintenance work area to opt into the offerings that meet your business requirements. Refer to the Oracle Applications Cloud Using Functional Setup Manager guide to manage the opt-in and setup of your offerings.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: By using the Financials offering, you can configure how you manage financial flows, including assets, ledgers, cash cycle, invoices and payments, accounts receivable, collections, and the setup of subledger accounting and tax configuration.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: The following table specifies the primary functional areas of this offering. For the full list of functional areas and features in this offering, use the Associated Features report that you review when you plan the implementation of your offering.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Functional Area Description

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Bill Management

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage system options and user registrations.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Budgetary Control and Encumbrance Accounting

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage control budgets and encumbrance accounting, along with data access for users. Public sector customers typically use this functional area.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Cash Management and Banking

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage banks, bank branches, and bank accounts. Additionally, define reconciliation matching rules, bank statement transaction creation rules, parse rules, transaction codes, and transaction type mapping. Furthermore, configure your cash positioning and cash forecasting options.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Collections

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage aging methods and collectors, as well as collections preferences, scoring data points, and strategy tasks.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Customer Billing

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage Receivables transactions and customer billing: AutoInvoice, payment terms, transaction types, transaction sources, memo lines, balance forward billing, and recurring billing.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Customer Payments

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage Receivables customer payments and receipts: receipt classes and methods, AutoCash rules, Application rules, AutoMatch, Lockbox.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Expenses

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage expense report templates, approval rules, and conversion rates and policies. If applicable, opt into using corporate cards for expenses, processing of expense receipt imaging, or integration with travel.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Financial Reporting Center

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage the financial tools to report and analyze accounting data: Financial Reporting Center, Smart View, Financial Reporting Studio, and Workspace.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Fixed Assets

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage asset locations, calendars, books and categories, along with depreciation methods.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: General Ledger

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage ledgers, accounting configurations, journal sources and categories, and other related accounting setup. If applicable, opt into configuring journal approval email notifications.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Intercompany

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage Intercompany transaction processing within Financials, intercompany balancing and reconciliation.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Joint Venture Management

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage the distribution of joint venture revenue and costs among joint venture partners while preserving essential data for tracking and auditing.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Payables

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage supplier invoice and payment options, payment terms, distribution sets, invoice tolerances, and procurement agents.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Payments

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage payment systems, payment methods, formats, and payment process profiles. If applicable, opt into deriving a bank account number from IBAN.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Receivables

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage the required setups to enable Receivables for transactions and receipts: Receivables system options; Receivables activities; AutoAccounting rules; remit-to addresses; and statement cycles.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Revenue Management

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage system options for revenue management, selling price profiles, hierarchies, resources, and Trading Community source systems.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Functional Area Description

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Revenue Recognition

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage revenue recognition for Receivables: revenue policies and revenue contingencies.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Suppliers

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Configure options for suppliers and supplier data.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Transaction Tax

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage tax configuration, including tax regimes, taxes, and tax rates.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: U.S. Federal Financials

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Manage the financial management system options specifically defined for U.S. Federal agencies.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud|Financials Offering
indexed_text: Note: Enable U.S. Federal Financials only if you are a U.S. federal agency. When you enable U.S. Federal Financials, you incorporate processes, data elements, reporting, and accounting methods specific to federal agencies.

indexed_text: Oracle Applications have been designed to ensure your enterprise can be modeled to meet legal and management objectives. The decisions about your implementation of Oracle Applications are affected by your:

indexed_text: Industry

indexed_text: Every enterprise has three fundamental structures that describe its operations and provide a basis for reporting.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Overview of Initial Configuration with the Enterprise Structures Configurator

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: The Enterprise Structures Configurator is an interview-based tool that guides you through the process of setting up a basic enterprise structure.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: By answering questions about your enterprise, the tool creates a structure of divisions, legal entities, business units, and reference data sets that reflects your enterprise structure. After you create your enterprise structure, you also follow a guided process to determine whether to use positions, and whether to set up additional attributes for jobs and positions. After you define your enterprise structure and your job and position structures, you can review them, make any necessary changes, and then load the final configuration.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: What happens if I don't use the Enterprise Structures Configurator to set up my enterprise structures?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: The Enterprise Structures Configurator is an interview-based tool that guides you through setting up divisions, legal entities, business units, and reference data sets.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: If you don't use the Enterprise Structures Configurator, then you must set up your enterprise structure using the individual tasks that correspond to each enterprise component. In addition, you can't set up multiple configurations and compare different scenarios. Using the Enterprise Structures Configurator is the recommended process for setting up your enterprise structures.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: What's an ultimate holding company?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: The legal entity that represents the top level in your organization hierarchy, as defined by the legal name entered for the enterprise. This designation is used only to create an organization tree, with these levels:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Ultimate holding company as the top level

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Divisions and country holding companies as the second level

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Legal employers as the third level

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Enterprise for Oracle Accounting Hub

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Define Enterprises

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: An enterprise is a collection of legal entities sharing common control and management.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Enterprise Defined

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: When implementing Oracle Fusion Cloud Applications you operate within the context of an enterprise that has already been created in the application for you. This is either a predefined enterprise or an enterprise that has been created in the application by a system administrator. An enterprise organization captures the name of the deploying enterprise and the location of the headquarters. In Oracle Fusion Applications, an organization classified as an enterprise is defined before defining any other organizations in the HCM Common Organization Model. All other organizations are defined as belonging to an enterprise.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Enterprise Information for Non-HCM Users

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: The Manage Enterprise HCM Information task includes default settings for your enterprise such as the employment model, worker number generation, and so on.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: If you're not implementing Oracle Fusion Human Capital Management (HCM), then the only action you may need to perform using this task is to change the enterprise name, if necessary. The other settings are HCM-specific and aren't relevant outside of Oracle Fusion HCM.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Overview of Legal Jurisdictions and Authorities

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: You are required to register your legal entities with legal authorities in the jurisdictions where you conduct business. Register your legal entities as required by local business requirements or other relevant laws.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: For example, register your legal entities for tax reporting to report sales taxes or value added taxes.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Define jurisdictions and related legal authorities to support multiple legal entity registrations, which are used by Oracle Fusion Tax and Oracle Fusion Payroll. When you create a legal entity, the Oracle Fusion Legal Entity Configurator automatically creates one legal reporting unit for that legal entity with a registration.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Overview of Geographies

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Setting up your geography structure and master geographies correctly in the Trading Community Model is critical to the proper use and management of Oracle Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) Cloud applications.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: The geography structure and master geography data is shared across multiple product families and applications. Address validation ensures complete and valid master address data across all location entities across product applications. In addition, complete and valid master data is critical for accurate transaction tax calculation.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: You can either define your geography structure and corresponding master geographies manually or import these geography entities. You can use the:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: 1. Manage Geographies page 2. Import Management process For more information about managing your geographies, see the Geographies section in the Define Enterprise Structures chapter in the Oracle ERP Cloud Implementing Common Features for Financials and Project Management guide on Oracle Help Center (https://docs.oracle.com).

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub|Manage Geographies
indexed_text: Use the Manage Geographies page to manually define your geography structure, hierarchy, mapping, and validation. Manually define your geographies when you have a simple geography requirement with a limited number of geographies within an individual country.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub|Import Management
indexed_text: Use the Import Management process to read the data included in your XML or text file and import the data into the application.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub|Import Management
indexed_text: To access Import Management functionality, go to Navigator > Tools > Import Management .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub|Import Management
indexed_text: For more information, see the Import Your Geography Data topic.

indexed_text: Overview of Legal Entities

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub|Import Management
indexed_text: A legal entity is a recognized party with rights and responsibilities given by legislation.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub|Import Management
indexed_text: Here are the rights and responsibilities of legal entities:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub|Import Management
indexed_text: Own property

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub|Import Management
indexed_text: Trade

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub|Import Management
indexed_text: Repay debt

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub|Import Management
indexed_text: Account for themselves to regulators, taxation authorities, and owners according to rules specified in the relevant legislation

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|2 Enterprise Structures for Oracle Accounting Hub|Import Management
indexed_text: Their rights and responsibilities may be enforced through the judicial system. Define a legal entity for each registered company or other entity recognized in law for which you want to record assets, liabilities, expenses and income, pay transaction taxes, or perform intercompany trading.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Overview of Financial Reporting Structure

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Define your enterprise structures in your chart of accounts to track and report on your financial objectives and meet your reporting requirements.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: The benefit of representing your enterprise in the chart of accounts is the functionality which includes multidimensional reporting with its Essbase tool. Segments included in the chart of accounts become dimensions in Essbase. The recorded data is automatically loaded into the Essbase cube when you post your journal entries. The Essbase tool includes powerful functionality for analysis and reporting on your financial data.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Chart of Accounts

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Overview of Chart of Accounts

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: The chart of accounts is the underlying structure for organizing financial information and reporting. An entity records transactions with a set of codes representing balances by type, expenses by function, and other divisional or organizational codes that are important to its business.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: The chart of accounts facilitates aggregating data from different operations, from within an operation, and from different business flows, thus enabling the organization to report using consistent definitions to their stakeholders in compliance with legislative and corporate reporting standards and aiding in management decisions.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Chart of Accounts

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Chart of Accounts Structures and Instances

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: In Oracle Fusion General Ledger, the chart of accounts model is framed around the concept of a chart of accounts structure, under which one or more chart of accounts structure instances can be created.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Consider the critical choices list here when creating your chart of accounts.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Chart of Accounts Structure

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: When creating the segments for the chart of accounts structure, you must enter segment sequence numbers that are consecutive and begin with the number one.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Chart of Accounts Structure Instance

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: For segments in your chart of account structure instance that you expect to contain a large number of distinct values, you must perform the following steps:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: In the chart of accounts definition, mark the segment query required option as selectively required . To perform searches in the transactional user interface, you have to specify the following segment as a mandatory search criteria .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Create required indexes in the GL_CODE_COMBINATIONS table for segments that are selectively required.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: CAUTION: For the Accounting Key Flexfield value sets used in your chart of accounts structure and instance, you must use independent validation only. If you use other validations, you may not be able to use the full chart of accounts functionality, such as data security, reporting, and account hierarchy integration.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Overview of Creating and Configuring Chart of Accounts Structure and Instances

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: In Oracle General Ledger, the chart of accounts model is framed around the concept of a chart of accounts structure, for which one or more chart of accounts structure instances can be created.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: A chart of accounts structure defines the key attributes for your chart of accounts. These attributes include the number of segments, the segment sequences, the segment names, segment prompts, segment labels, for example natural account and primary balancing, and default value sets.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: How can I use future accounting segments?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: To plan for future growth in the business organization that requires additional segments in the chart of accounts. Extra segments can be added to the chart of accounts structure during your original implementation.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: All segments of the chart of accounts are required and have to be enabled. The unused segments can be assigned value sets that have a single value in the chart of accounts structure instance. The value is set as a default for that segment so that the extra segments are automatically populated when an account account combination is used.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Overview of Value Sets

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: A value set is a group of valid values that you assign to a flexfield segment to control the values that are stored for business object attributes.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: A user enters a value for an attribute of a business object while using the application. The flexfield validates the value against the set of valid values that you configured as a value set and assigned to the segment.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Overview of Value Sets

indexed_text: Account Hierarchies

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Overview of Trees

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Trees are hierarchical data models that you can use to organize data, apply business rules, control data access, and improve performance while querying.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: For example, an application maintains data of an organization called Vision Corporation that has two departments: Marketing and Finance. The Finance department has two functional divisions: Receivables and Payables. You can define a tree for Vision Corporation to establish a hierarchy across its departments, and their respective functional divisions. You can use the hierarchy to manage data at various levels of the organization.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: To work with trees, in the Setup and Maintenance work area, use any of the following tasks:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Manage Tree Structures: To create and update tree structures. You must first define a tree structure to create a tree.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Manage Trees and Tree Versions: To create and update trees and their versions.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Manage Tree Labels: To create and update tree labels.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Tree Structures

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: As the name suggests, tree structures provide you the framework to organize data such that you can establish a hierarchy for use by the tree. So, similar to a template, a tree structure guides the creation of a tree.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Tree

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: A tree is an instance of the tree structure. The root node is the highest nodal point of a tree. Child nodes branch off from the root node. Child nodes at the same level, branching off from a common parent node, are called siblings. Leaves are

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: details branching off from a node but not extending further down the tree hierarchy. You can create trees for multiple data sources and share them across applications.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Tree Versions

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: A tree by default has only one version. If required, you can create and maintain more than one editable tree version. At any point, only one tree version must be active. If you edit an existing version, it changes from active to draft. To use it again, you must set it to active. Similar to any other version control system, versions of trees are maintained to track all the changes that a tree undergoes in its life cycle.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Tree Labels

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Tree labels are short names given to trees and tree structures. You can label the tree versions for better accessibility and information retrieval. When nodes are created in a tree, the existing tree labels are automatically assigned to the new tree nodes. You can use any table to store the labels and register the label data source with the tree structure.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Tree Labels

indexed_text: Tree Structures

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Overview of Managing Account Hierarchies

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Account hierarchies are defined in Oracle Fusion applications using tree functionality. Each account hierarchy is defined as a tree with one or more versions. Tree versions are used to track account hierarchies as they change over time.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: For example, an account hierarchy to summarize cost of goods has different accounts for 2011, versus 2010. The changes are in the business operations and affect the chart of accounts values.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Chart of accounts values can be associated with multiple hierarchies by defining multiple trees. Using multiple trees enable create financial reports for different target audiences. For example, you can use different hierarchies to track cost centers either by geography or line of business.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Before setting up hierarchies, you may want to consider different hierarchy requirements for financial reporting, allocations, cross validation rules, revaluations, and chart of accounts mapping.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: This topic describes the best practices of maintaining and publishing the account hierarchies. Account hierarchies are used throughout Oracle Fusion General Ledger for creating financial reports, Smart View inquiries, allocation definitions, cross validation rules, and revaluation definitions.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: FAQs for Manage Account Hierarchies

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: How can I manage and review account hierarchies?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: View segment value descriptions when creating, editing, or reviewing account hierarchies online. You can also export account hierarchies to a spreadsheet to review, analyze, and report offline.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: To export all nodes in the hierarchies to a spreadsheet, expand all nodes first from View -> Expand All in the Manage Account Hierarchies: Specify Nodes page.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: When do I manually submit row and column flattening for tree versions?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Row Flattening and Column Flattening for tree versions must be manually submitted in the following scenarios.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: A new tree or tree version is defined

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: If the tree or tree version has any change made to it that would alter the flattened hierarchy data. For example, adding, moving, and duplicating members. Basically, anything that impacts the flattened hierarchy data.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: If Data Relationship Management (DRM) is used with Oracle General Ledger, after running the Load Account Values and Hierarchies process from the Scheduled Process work area to load chart of accounts reference data from DRM to General Ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: When range based hierarchy assignments are supported, if new values are added that are within the account range assigned to the hierarchy.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Note: In this case, try submitting the flattening programs using the Online Mode first. If the newly inserted child account value does not appear to be included in the flattened hierarchy data, then the flattening program has to be submitted using the Force Flattening Mode , instead of Online Flattening . An issue with the incremental flattening programs can prevent them from picking up this type of hierarchy change, so full flattening can be required.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Note: Column flattening processed data is primarily relevant to Oracle Fusion Transactional Business Intelligence, but there should not be any adverse impact to run both row and column flattening processes.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Overview of Managing Tree Structures

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: A tree structure defines the hierarchy for creating trees and prescribes rules based on which trees are created, versioned, and accessed. You can associate multiple data sources with a tree structure.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: A tree is an instance of this hierarchy. Every tree structure can contain one or more trees.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: You can create tree structures specific to an application but you can share tree structures across applications. If you apply version control to the tree structure, it's carried over to the trees that are based on the tree structure. Each tree version contains at least one root node. Occasionally, a tree version may have more than one root node.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: An administrator controls the access to tree structures through a set of rules that are periodically audited for validity.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Tree Labels

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Tree labels are tags that are stored on tree nodes. You can store labels in any table and register the label data source with the tree structure.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: When a labeling scheme is used for trees, the selected labels are stored in the tree label entity, and each tree node contains a reference to a tree label in the labeling scheme. The following table lists the three ways in which tree labels are assigned to the tree nodes.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Labeling Scheme Description

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Level

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Labels that are automatically assigned based on the data source to which the tree node belongs. A level label points to a specific data source. For example, in a tree that reflects the organizational hierarchy of an enterprise, all division nodes appear on one level and all department nodes on another.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Group

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Labels that you can arbitrarily assign to tree nodes.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Depth

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Labels that are automatically assigned based on the depth of the tree node within the tree. No manual assignment is performed.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Note: In an unbalanced hierarchy, a level may not be equal to depth.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Overview of Managing Tree Versions

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: You can create and edit trees and tree versions depending upon the requirement. A tree can have one or more tree versions. When you change an existing tree, a new version is created and published.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: You can use the tree version audit results to verify the tree version's correctness and data integrity.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Segment Labels

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Segment labels identify certain segments in your chart of accounts structure and assign special functionality to those segments. Best practice is to assign each segment label one time within the chart of accounts structure.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Here are the segment labels that are available to use with the chart of accounts.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: CAUTION: Validations aren't performed when segment labels are assigned, so verify that all are assigned correctly before using your chart of accounts.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Balancing

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Ensures that all journals balance for each balancing segment value or combination of multiple balancing segment values. You can secure access to your primary balancing segment values only with data access sets. The General Ledger application automatically calculates and creates balancing lines as required in journal entries. For example, recognizing an entity's receivable and the other entity's payable. The three balancing segment labels are primary, second, and third balancing. The primary balancing segment label is required.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Cost Center

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Represents the smallest segment of an organization for which costs are collected and reported. Facilitates grouping of natural accounts by functional cost types, accommodating tracking of specific business expenses across natural accounts. As cost centers combine expenses and headcount data into costs, they're useful for detailed analysis and reporting. Cost centers are optional, but required for:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Tracking depreciation, additions, and other transactions in Oracle Fusion Assets.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Storing expense approval limits in Oracle Fusion Expense.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Natural Account

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Determines the account type (asset, liability, expense, revenue, or equity), whether posting is allowed, and other information specific to the segment value. The natural account segment is mapped to the Financial Category dimension in the balances cube to enable ad hoc reporting and transactional dashboards. This functionality uses Oracle Fusion Business Intelligence Enterprise Edition to analyze and drill into expense and revenue transactions. The natural account segment label is required.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Intercompany

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Optionally, assign the segment to be used in intercompany balancing functionality. You can't use the primary balancing or natural account segments as the intercompany segment. You can assign the same values to both the primary balancing and intercompany value sets. You can also assign the same value set to the primary balancing segment and the intercompany segment. The sharing of the value set or values:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Enables clear visibility of the due to and due from relationships inherent in intercompany accounting across the entire organization.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Saves maintenance and ensure completeness.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: However, sharing value sets can cause problems when applying segment value security rules because the rules applied to both segments. The rules can restrict access to certain values which may complicate entering intercompany entries. For example, you might have access to company 01 at the balancing segment level but not company 02. As a result, you can't enter an intercompany entry for transactions between 01 and 02.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Example of Segment Labels

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: For a chart of accounts, each segment can be qualified by a label to distinctly indicate its purpose. The label designation is used by Oracle Fusion General Ledger processes to determine how to display and process transactions and balances that are recorded.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Scenario

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: You are creating your chart of accounts with six segments. General Ledger permits selection of up to 30 segments for your chart of accounts. You must have a minimum of three required segments, as determined by the number of required segment labels (qualifiers). Required segment labels are:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Primary Balancing Segment: Main balancing segment typically used to represent the company dimension of the organization. The segment set with this label can't be set with another label.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Cost Center Segment: Smallest segment of an organization for which you collect and report costs. You are required to create this segment if you're implementing Oracle Fusion Assets.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Natural Account Segment: Classification of transactions and balances according to distinct account types: asset, liability, equity, revenue, and expense accounts. The segment set with this label can't be set with another label.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: The following optional segment labels are available, and you are implementing all of them:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Second Balancing Segment: Used to balance transactions, as needed, by an additional dimension beyond the primary balancing segment.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Third Balancing Segment: Used to balance transactions, as needed, by an additional dimension beyond the primary and second balancing segments.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Intercompany Segment: Used to track intercompany due to and due from balances by identifying the specific trading company. The intercompany qualified segment cannot be set with any of the three balancing segment qualifiers. The values in this segment's value set must be the same as the primary balancing segment.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Segment labels can only be assigned once within a chart of accounts. The following table shows the segment labels that are assigned to each segment in the chart of accounts.

indexed_text: Note: Validations aren't performed when segment labels are assigned, so verify that all are assigned correctly before using your chart of accounts.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: For Oracle Transactional Business Intelligence reporting, all labeled segments of the chart of accounts are automatically maintained in the data that reporting is based on. The granularity of information stored in the nonqualified segments is summarized and Oracle Transactional Business Intelligence isn't able to provide detailed reporting by segments. To maintain the ability to perform detailed reporting on such segments, create user-defined labels to qualify these segments.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: For example, one of the segments of the chart of accounts is based on product line, and none of the segment labels are applicable. The organization must derive product line-based Oracle Transactional Business Intelligence reports. Create a user-defined label called Product Line to use to qualify the Product Line segment of the chart of accounts.

indexed_text: Overview of Balancing Segments

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Balancing segments ensure that all journals balance for each balancing segment value or combination of multiple balancing segment values. You can secure access to your primary balancing segment values only with data access sets.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: The General Ledger application automatically calculates and creates balancing lines as required in journal entries. By enabling multiple balancing segments for your chart of accounts, you can produce financial statements for each unique combination of segment values across one, two, or three qualified balancing segments. This ability provides you greater insights into your operations as it affords you visibility along the critical fiscal dimensions you use to plan, monitor, and measure your financial performance.
