section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Examples of Segment Value Inheritance

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: The Inherit Segment Value Attributes process simplifies the chart of accounts maintenance.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: When the characteristics of values in the value sets are updated, such as changes to enabled status, effective date, posting allowed status, or natural account type, all previously created account combinations that referenced such values aren't automatically updated by these changes. The Inherit Segment Value Attributes process lets you run a controlled process to update such existing account combinations. This process maintains and corrects the current attribute settings for those account combinations that contain the account values that were changed.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: For account combinations where the present settings must be retained and not impacted by account attribute changes, activate the option to preserve the account combination's attributes. The Preserve Attributes option can be found on the Manage Account Combinations page. Activating the option prevents those account combination's attributes from being updated when the Inherit Segment Value Attributes process is run.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Scenario

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: For example, there are three inactive account combinations that share a common inactive cost center value of 110. The following table lists each account combination, indicates whether the account combination is enabled, and indicates how the Preserve Attributes option is set.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: FAQs for Maintain Segment Values Attributes

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: How can I change segments in an existing chart of accounts structure?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: The chart of accounts structure and structure instance are fundamental constructs in General Ledger accounting setup and can't be altered once they're used. The number of segments, the segments' order, each segment's label, length, type, and value set assignment can't be updated.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: These components set the foundation upon which accounting data is recorded for ledgers that use them. Careful and thoughtful planning must precede all decisions pertaining to defining the chart of accounts.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Overview of Deploying Flexfield

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Deployment generates or refreshes the Application Development Framework (ADF) business component objects that render the flexfield in a user interface. The deployment process adds user-defined attributes to the Web Services Description Language (WSDL) schemas exposed by Oracle ADF services and used by SOA composites.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Flexfields are deployed for the first time during the application provisioning process. After you configure or change a flexfield, you must deploy it to make the latest definition available to users.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: If a descriptive flexfield is enabled for business intelligence, the deployment process redeploys the flexfield's business intelligence artifacts.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: You can deploy a flexfield to a sandbox for testing or to the mainline metadata for use in a test or production run time environment. You can deploy extensible flexfields as a background process.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: After deployment, the user-defined attributes are available for incorporating into the SOA infrastructure, such as business process and business rule integration. For example, you can now write business rules that depend on the user- defined attributes. You must sign out and sign back in to Oracle Applications Cloud to see the changes you deployed at run time.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: The rapid implementation solution provides a template for defining cross-validation rules in a spreadsheet.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Cross-validation rules determine whether a selected value for a particular segment of an account combination can be combined with specific values in the other segments to form a new account combination.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: In the Setup and Maintenance work area, use the following:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Offering: Financials

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Note: The spreadsheet can only create cross-validation rules. To update existing cross-validation rules, use the Manage Cross-Validation Rules task in the Setup and Maintenance work area.

indexed_text: Overview of Managing Cross-Validation Rules

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: You can use cross-validation rules to determine the valid account combinations that can be dynamically created as users enter transactions or journal entries. You can also control the creation of new key flexfield code combinations by defining cross-validation rules.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Once enabled, a cross-validation rule determines whether a selected value for a particular segment of an account combination can be combined with specific values in other segments to form a new account combination.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Segment Rules and Account Rules for Chart of Accounts Mapping

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: The chart of accounts mapping feature supports the ability to correlate a source chart of accounts to a target chart of accounts to allow for the processing of balances or amounts.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: Use either segment rules, account rules, or a combination of both. A chart of accounts mapping is used by the posting process in propagating transactions from the primary ledger to its secondary ledger. The mapping feature is used by both balance transfer processes for balance level secondary ledgers as well as cross ledger transfers. The balances are copied from one ledger to another ledger in both processes.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures
indexed_text: You can define chart of accounts mappings using the Manage Chart of Accounts Mapping task. If youre defining mappings that include only segment rules, you can also use the Chart of Accounts Mapping Rules Import file-based data import (FBDI).

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Segment Rules
indexed_text: Use segment rules to map each segment of the target chart of accounts to an account value, or to one or two segments in the source chart of accounts. You can select from among three different mapping methods:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Segment Rules
indexed_text: Assign a constant value for a segment in the target chart of accounts.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Segment Rules
indexed_text: Copy the value from the source segment to the corresponding target segment.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Segment Rules
indexed_text: Note: To use this method, the value sets for the paired target and source segments must share identical values.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Segment Rules
indexed_text: Use rollup rules to aggregate one or two source segments to a corresponding target segment.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Account rules map a complete target account combination against one or more source account combinations. The source account combinations can be defined segment by segment using:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Single detail account values

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Detail account value ranges

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Parent values for primary balancing and natural account segments

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Note: When using parent values, its child values for the date effective version of the hierarchy are processed when the mapping is called.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: FAQ for Manage Chart of Accounts Mapping

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: What's the difference between mapping with segment rules and mapping with account rules?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Segment rules map target chart of accounts segments to an account value or segment of the source account of a secondary chart of accounts. A segment is only one part of the account combination.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Account rules map a complete target account combination against one or more source account combinations.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Note: Segment and account rules can be used alone or both types of mapping rules can be used in the same mapping set.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: When do account rules override segment rules in a chart of accounts mapping?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: You can create a chart of accounts mapping using only segment rules, only account rules, or a combination of both segment and account rules. If an overlap exists between the two types of rule, the account rule supersedes.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Segment rules are used to broadly define the relationship between two charts of accounts on a segment by segment basis. Account rules can be used to more precisely map specific source account combinations to their target accounts.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Overview of Defining Calendars

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Define an accounting calendar to create your accounting year and the periods it contains. Specify common calendar options that the application uses to automatically generate a calendar with its periods.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Specifying all the options makes defining a correct calendar easier and more intuitive with fewer errors.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Accounting Calendar Options

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: How Accounting Calendars Are Validated

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: FAQs for Define Calendars

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: How can I identify errors in my accounting calendar?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Erroneous entries are identified online as you enter a new calendar or change data on an existing calendar. The application also automatically validates the data when you save the calendar.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: What's the difference between calendar and fiscal period naming?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: The period naming format determines the year that's appended to the prefix for each period in the calendar.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: For the example, your accounting year has a set of twelve accounting period with:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Start date of September 1, 2014.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: End date is August 31, 2015.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Period's date range following the natural calendar month date range.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Calendar period naming format: Select the calendar period format to append the period's start date's year to the prefix. For the period covering September 1, 2014 to December 31, 2014, then 2014 or just 14, depending on the period format selected, is appended to each period's name. For the remaining periods covering January 1, 2015 to August 31, 2015, then 2015 or 15, is appended to each period's name.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Fiscal period naming format: Select the fiscal period format to always append the period's year assignment to the prefix. If the accounting periods in the set of twelve are all assigned the year of 2015, then 2015 or just 15, depending on the period format selected, is appended to the period name of all 12 periods.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: When do I update an existing calendar?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Update an existing calendar before the new periods are needed as future periods, based on the future period setting in your accounting configuration.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: If a complete year has been defined and validated, use the Add Year button to add the next year quickly. Accept or change the new rows as required. For example, with the Other frequency type calendar, dates may differ from what the application generates.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: What happens if I upgrade my calendar from Oracle E-Business Suite Release 12?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: What happens if I upgrade my calendar from Oracle E-Business Suite Release 12?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: The migration script assigns a period frequency that most closely matches your Oracle E-Business Suite Release 12 calendar.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: When you use the Oracle Fusion Cloud Applications Add Year functionality for the first time, you have an opportunity to review and change the period frequency. The Calendar Options page opens only for calendars upgraded from Release 12 to allow a one time modification.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Make your changes to the period frequency, adjusting period frequency, and period name format, including the prefix and separator, as needed. Changes cannot conflict with the existing upgraded calendar definition. Update the calendar name and description in the calendar header, as needed, for all calendars. Period details for a new year are generated automatically based on the latest calendar options. You can also manually update the calendar. The modified calendar options affect future years only.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Currencies

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Considerations for Defining Currencies

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Consider these points about entering the currency code, date range, or symbol for the currency, when you create or edit currencies.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Currency Codes

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: You can't change a currency code after you enable the currency, even if you later disable that currency.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Date Ranges

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: You can enter transactions denominated in the currency only for the dates within the specified range. If you don't enter a start date, then the currency is valid immediately. If you don't enter an end date, then the currency is valid indefinitely.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Symbols

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Some applications support displaying currency symbols. You may enter the symbol associated with a currency so that it appears along with the amount.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: What's the difference between precision, extended precision, and minimum accountable unit for a currency?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: What's a statistical unit currency type?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Euro Currency Derivation

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Euro Currency Derivation

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Use the Derivation Type, Derivation Factor, and Derivation Effective Date fields to define the relationship between the official currency (Euro) of the European Monetary Union (EMU) and the national currencies of EMU member states.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: For each EMU currency, you define its Euro-to-EMU fixed conversion rate and the effective starting date. If you have to use a different currency for Euro, you can disable the predefined currency and create a new one.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Derivation Type

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: The Euro currency derivation type is used only for the Euro, and the Euro derived derivation type identifies national currencies of EMU member states. All other currencies don't have derivation types.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Derivation Factor

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: The derivation factor is the fixed conversion rate by which you multiply one Euro to derive the equivalent EMU currency amount. The Euro currency itself must not have a derivation factor.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Derivation Effective Date

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: The derivation effective date is the date on which the relationship between the EMU currency and the Euro begins.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: FAQs for Manage Currencies

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: When do I create or enable currencies?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Create or enable any currency for displaying monetary amounts, assigning currency to ledgers, entering transactions, recording balances, or for any reporting purpose. All currencies listed in the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) 4217 standard are supported.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: The default currency is set to United States Dollar (USD).

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Considerations for Defining Currencies

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: What's the difference between precision, extended precision, and minimum accountable unit for a currency?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Precision refers to the number of digits placed after the decimal point used in regular currency transactions. For example, USD would have 2 as the precision value for transactional amounts, such as $1.00.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Extended precision is the number of digits placed after the decimal point and must be greater than or equal to the precision value. For calculations requiring greater precision, you can enter an extended precision value such as 3 or 4. That would result in the currency appearing as $1.279 or $1.2793.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Minimum accountable unit is the smallest denomination for the currency. For example, for USD that would be .01 for a cent.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: You can set these values for a currency using the Manage Currencies task in the Application Extensions functional area in the Setup and Maintenance work area.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Note: When setting up currencies, make sure you use the correct precision. Some currencies, for example, the Chilean peso, dont support precision at all.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Conversion Rate Types

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Guidelines for Creating Conversion Rate Types

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Maintain different conversion rates between currencies for the same period using conversion rate types.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: The following conversion rate types are predefined:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Spot

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Corporate

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: User

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Fixed

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: You can use different rate types for different business needs. During journal entry, the conversion rate is provided automatically based on the selected conversion rate type and currency, unless the rate type is User . For User rate types, you must enter a conversion rate. You can define additional rate types as needed. Set your most frequently used rate type as the default. Conversion rate types can't be deleted.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Assign conversion rate types to automatically populate the associated rate for your period average and period end rates for the ledger. For example, you can assign the conversion rate type of Spot to populate period average rates, and the conversion rate type of Corporate to populate period end rates. Period average and period end rates are used in translation of account balances.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Conversion rate types are used to automatically assign a rate when you perform the following accounting functions:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Convert foreign currency journal amounts to ledger currency equivalents.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Convert journal amounts from source ledgers to reporting currencies or secondary ledgers.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Run revaluation or translation processes.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: When creating conversion rates, decide whether to:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Enforce inverse relationships

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Select pivot currencies

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Select contra currencies

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Enable cross rates and allow cross-rate overrides

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Maintain cross-rate rules

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Enforce Inverse Relationships

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: The Enforce Inverse Relationship option indicates whether to enforce the automatic calculation of inverse conversion rates when defining daily rates. The following table describes the impact of selecting or not selecting the option.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Action Results

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Selected

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: When you enter a daily rate to convert currency A to currency B, the inverse rate of currency B to currency A is automatically calculated and entered in the adjacent column. If either rate is changed, the application automatically recalculates the other rate. You can update the application calculated inverse rate, but once you do, the related rate is updated. The option enforces the inverse relationship is maintained but doesn't prevent you from updating the rates.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Not Selected

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: The inverse rate is calculated, but you can change the rate and update the daily rates table without the corresponding rate being updated.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Select Pivot Currencies

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Select a pivot currency that's commonly used in your currency conversions. A pivot currency is the central currency that interacts with contra currencies. For example, you set up a daily rate between the US dollar (USD) and the Euro currency (EUR) and another between the USD and the Canadian dollar (CAD). USD is the pivot currency in creating a rate between EUR and CAD. EUR and CAD are the contra currencies. Select the pivot currency from the list of values which contains those currencies that are enabled, effective, and not a statistical (STAT) currency. The description of the pivot currency is populated automatically based on the currency definition.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: If you want the application to create cross rates against a base currency, define the base currency as the pivot currency. Selected pivot currencies can be changed in the Rate Types page.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Select Contra Currencies

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Select currencies available on the list of values as contra currencies. The available currencies are those currencies which are enabled, effective, not STAT currency, and not the pivot currency selected earlier. The description of the contra currency is populated automatically based on the currency definition. Add or delete contra currencies in the Contra Currencies region of the Rate Types page.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Enable Cross Rates and Allow Cross Rate Overrides

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Check the Enable Cross Rates check box to calculate conversion rates based on defined currency rate relationships. General Ledger calculates cross rates based on your defined cross rate rules. Associate your cross rate rules with a conversion rate type, pivot currency, and contra currencies. Cross rates facilitate the creation of daily rates by automatically creating the rates between contra currencies based on their relationship to a pivot currency. If the Enable Cross Rates option is deselected after entering contra currencies, the application stops calculating cross rates going forward for that particular rate type. All the earlier calculated cross rates for that rate type remain in the database unless you manually delete them.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: For example, if you have daily rates defined for the pivot currency, USD to the contra currency, EUR, and USD to another contra currency, CAD, the application automatically creates the rates between EUR to CAD and CAD to EUR. You don't have to manually define the EUR to CAD and CAD to EUR rates.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Select the Allow Cross Rates Override check box to permit your users to override application generated cross rates. If you accept the default of not selected, the application generated cross rates can't be overridden.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Maintain Cross Rate Rules

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Define or update your cross rate rules at any time by adding or removing contra currency assignments. Add a contra currency to a cross rate rule and run the Daily Rates Import and Calculation process to generate the new rates. If you remove a cross rate rule or a contra currency from a rule, any cross rates generated previously for that contra currency remain unless you manually delete them. Changes to the rule aren't retroactive and don't affect previously stored cross rates. The Cross Rate process generates as many rates as possible and skips currencies where one component of the set is missing.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Note: With a defined web service that extracts daily currency conversion rates from external services, for example Reuters, currency conversion rates are automatically updated for the daily rates and all cross currency relationships.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Examples of Using Conversion Rate Types in a Journal

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: The following conversion rate types are predefined: Spot, Corporate, User, Fixed.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Scenario

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: You are the general ledger accountant for Vision US Inc. You are entering a journal entry to capture three transactions that were transacted in three different foreign currencies.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Canadian Dollar CAD: A stable currency

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Mexican Peso MXP: A fluctuating currency

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Hong Kong Dollar HKD: An infrequently used currency

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: You enter two journal lines with accounts and amounts for each foreign currency transaction. Based on your company procedures, you select the rate type to populate the rate for Corporate and Spot rate types from your daily rates table. You manually enter the current rate for the User rate type.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: The following table lists the currency, the rate type that you select, and the reasons for the rate type selection.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Selected Currency Selected Rate Type Reason

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: CAD

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Corporate

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Entered a periodic type of transaction. Your company has established a daily rate to use for the entire month across divisions for all transactions in Canadian dollars, a stable currency that fluctuates only slightly over the month.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Selected Currency Selected Rate Type Reason

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: MXP

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Spot

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Entered a periodic type of transaction. Your company enters daily rates each day for the Mexican peso because the currency is unstable and fluctuates.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: HKD

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: User

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Entered a one time transaction. Your company doesn't maintain daily rates for Hong Kong dollars.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Your company doesn't currently use the Fixed rate type. From January 1, 1999, the conversion rate of the French franc FRF against the Euro EUR was a fixed rate of 1 EUR to 6.55957 FRF. Your French operations were started in 2007, so you maintain all your French business records in the Euro.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: FAQs for Manage Conversion Rate Types

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: What's the difference between spot, corporate, user, and fixed rate types?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Spot, corporate, user, and fixed conversion rate types differ based on fluctuations of the entered foreign currency and your company procedures for maintaining daily rates.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Spot: For currencies with fluctuating conversion rates, or when exact currency conversion is needed.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Corporate: For setting a standard rate across your organization for a stable currency.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: User: For infrequent entries where daily rates for the entered foreign currency aren't set up.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Fixed: For rates where the conversion is constant between two currencies.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: If you have infrequent foreign currency transactions, the User rate type can simplify currency maintenance. The User rate type can also provide an accurate conversion rate on the date of the transaction.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: What's a statistical unit currency type?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: The statistical unit currency type denotes the Statistical (STAT) currency used to record financial statistics in the financial reports, allocation formulas, and other calculations.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Daily Currency Rates

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Overview of GL Currency Rates Upload

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Oracle Fusion Cloud ERP has various options to load currency rates. Daily currency conversion rates can be maintained between any two currencies. You can enter daily conversion rates for specific combinations of foreign currency, date, and conversion rate type.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Oracle Cloud ERP automatically calculates inverse rates. You can override the inverse rates that are automatically calculated.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: The three different methods of loading currency rates are:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: 1. Manual load using the Create Daily Rates spreadsheet. 2. Manual load using the Import and Calculate Daily Rates file-based data import. 3. Automatic load using web services.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Required Security for Loading GL Currency Rates

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Enter Daily Rates Using the Daily Rates Spreadsheet

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: How Daily Rate Import Data Is Processed

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Update Currency Rates

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: You're required to change today's daily rates that were already entered. The rates you're changing are for currency conversion from Great Britain pounds sterling (GBP) to United States dollars (USD) for your company InFusion America.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Currency conversion rates were entered by an automatic load to the Daily Rates table. They can also be entered through a spreadsheet.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Updating Currency Rates

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: 1. Navigate to the Period Close work area.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Use the Period Close work area to link to close processes and currency process. 2. Click the Manage Currency Rates link.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Use the Currency Rates Manager page to create, edit, and review currency rate types, daily rates, and historical rates. 3. Click the Daily Rates tab.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Use the Daily Rates tab to review and enter currency rates. 4. Click the From Currency list. Select the GBP - Pound Sterling list item. 5. Click the To Currency list. Select the USD - US Dollar list item. 6. Enter the dates for the daily rates that you are changing. Enter today's date. 7. Click the Rate Type list. Select the Spot list item.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: 8. Click the Search button. 9. Click in the Rate field. Enter the new rate of 1.7 in the Rate field. 10. Click in the Inverse Rate field. Enter the new inverse rate of 0.58822 in the Inverse Rate field. 11. Click the Save button.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|3 Financial Reporting Structures|Account Rules
indexed_text: Guidelines for Using Desktop Integrated Excel Workbooks

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers
indexed_text: Overview of Ledger and Subledgers

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers
indexed_text: Oracle Fusion Applications reflect the traditional segregation between the general ledger and associated subledgers. Detailed transactional information is captured in the subledgers and periodically imported and posted in summary or detail to the ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers
indexed_text: A ledger determines the currency, chart of accounts, accounting calendar, ledger processing options, and accounting method for its associated subledgers. Each accounting setup requires a primary ledger and optionally, one or more secondary ledgers and reporting currencies. Reporting currencies are associated with either a primary or secondary ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers
indexed_text: The number of ledgers and subledgers is unlimited and determined by your business structure and reporting requirements.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers
indexed_text: Ledgers and Subledgers

indexed_text: Create a Primary Ledger

indexed_text: Specify Ledger Options

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers
indexed_text: FAQs for Specify Ledger Options

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers
indexed_text: What happens if I change the cumulative translation adjustment account?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers
indexed_text: Changing the cumulative translation adjustment (CTA) account is a very significant revision to your accounting configuration and should be avoided if possible. To prevent data corruption, your CTA can only be changed if you delete translated balances.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers
indexed_text: How Translated Balances Are Deleted

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers
indexed_text: What happens if I change the retained earnings account?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers
indexed_text: Changing the retained earnings account is a very significant revision to your accounting configuration and should be avoided if possible.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers
indexed_text: To prevent data corruption, your retained earnings account can only be changed if you first perform the following set of steps:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers
indexed_text: 1. To reverse what was closed out to the incorrect retained earnings account, enter and post journals to bring the ending balances for your income statement accounts to zero at the end of each accounting year. Use a temporary account, such as a suspense account, for the offsetting amount. 2. Update the retained earnings account. 3. Reverse the journal entries used to bring the income statement accounts' ending account balances to zero to reinstate each accounting year's profit and loss, and now close these out to the new retained earning's account in the following accounting year.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers
indexed_text: Note: The recommended reversal method for the journals is Change Sign .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers
indexed_text: 4. If you have translated balances for the ledger, follow the process of deleting translated balances for a change in the retained earnings account.

However, you can't see the data associated with company 100 in your report.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Settings That Affect Reporting Currency Balances
indexed_text: Reporting currencies share a majority of the ledger options with their source ledger. For example, the reporting currency uses the same suspense account and retained earnings accounts as its source ledger. However, there are certain options that must be set specifically for reporting currencies, such as the currency conversion level. The currency conversion levels are Balance, Journal, and Subledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Settings That Affect Reporting Currency Balances
indexed_text: Note: Secondary ledgers can't use subledger level reporting currencies.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Settings That Affect Reporting Currency Balances
indexed_text: Multiple dependencies exist between a reporting currency and its source ledger. Therefore, complete your period opening tasks, daily journal or subledger level reporting currencies accounting tasks, and period closing tasks in the correct order. The following table describes some of the tasks for each task type.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Settings That Affect Reporting Currency Balances
indexed_text: Type Tasks

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Settings That Affect Reporting Currency Balances
indexed_text: Period Opening

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Settings That Affect Reporting Currency Balances
indexed_text: Open the accounting period in both your ledger and reporting currencies before you create or import journals for the period. Converted journals are only generated in your reporting currency if the period is open or future enterable.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Settings That Affect Reporting Currency Balances
indexed_text: Daily

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Settings That Affect Reporting Currency Balances
indexed_text: Enter daily conversion rates to convert journals to each of the reporting currencies.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Settings That Affect Reporting Currency Balances
indexed_text: Period Closing

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Settings That Affect Reporting Currency Balances
indexed_text: Finish entering all regular and adjusting journals for the period in your ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Settings That Affect Reporting Currency Balances
indexed_text: Post all unposted journals in your ledger if not already done in the previous step.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Settings That Affect Reporting Currency Balances
indexed_text: Post all unposted journals in your reporting currencies if not already done in the previous step.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Settings That Affect Reporting Currency Balances
indexed_text: Run revaluation in both your ledger and reporting currencies. Post the resulting revaluation batches in each ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Settings That Affect Reporting Currency Balances
indexed_text: As needed, translate balances in your ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Settings That Affect Reporting Currency Balances
indexed_text: Generate needed reports from both your ledger and reporting currencies.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Settings That Affect Reporting Currency Balances
indexed_text: Close your accounting period in both your ledger and reporting currencies.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated
indexed_text: If you use reporting currencies at the journal or subledger level, journals are posted in your reporting currency when you:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated
indexed_text: Create accounting.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated
indexed_text: Post journal entries.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated
indexed_text: Translate balances.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated
indexed_text: General Ledger and Subledger Accounting automatically generate journals in your reporting currencies where the entered currency amounts are converted to the reporting currency amounts. Other factors used in the calculation of reporting currency balances are listed:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated
indexed_text: Manual Journals: Enter a manual journal batch in your reporting currency at the journal or subledger level by using the Create Journals page. Select the journal or subledger level reporting currency from the ledger's list of values. Continue in the same manner as entering any other manual journal.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated
indexed_text: Conversion Rounding: Use the reporting currency functionality to round converted and accounted amounts using the same rounding rules used throughout your Oracle Fusion Cloud Applications. The reporting currency functionality considers several factors that are a part of the currencies predefined in your applications, including:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated|Currency Precision: Number of digits after the decimal point used in currency transactions. Minimum Accountable Unit: Smallest denomination used in the currency. This might not correspond to the precision.
indexed_text: Converted Journals: Generate and post automatically journals in your reporting currencies when you post the original journals in the source ledger for the following types of journals:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated|Unposted journals from any Oracle subledger that doesn't support reporting currency transfer and import Optionally, revaluation journals
indexed_text: Unconverted Journals: Rely on the subledger accounting functionality to convert and transfer Oracle subledger journals, for both the original journal and the reporting currency journal, to the General Ledger for import and posting. The reporting currency conversion for these journals isn't performed by the General Ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated|Unposted journals from any Oracle subledger that doesn't support reporting currency transfer and import Optionally, revaluation journals
indexed_text: Approving Journals: Use the journal approval feature to process reporting currency journals through your organization's approval hierarchy. You can enable journal approval functionality separately in your source ledger and reporting currencies.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated|Unposted journals from any Oracle subledger that doesn't support reporting currency transfer and import Optionally, revaluation journals
indexed_text: Document Numbers: Accept the default document numbers assigned by the General Ledger application to your journal when you enter a journal in your ledger. The converted journal in the reporting currency is assigned the same document number. However, if you enter a journal in the reporting currency, the document number assigned to the journal is determined by the reporting currency.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated|Unposted journals from any Oracle subledger that doesn't support reporting currency transfer and import Optionally, revaluation journals
indexed_text: Sequential Numbering: Enable sequential numbering to maintain the same numbering in your reporting currency and source ledger for journals, other than those journals for Oracle subledgers. Don't create separate sequences for your reporting currencies. If you do, the sequence defined for the reporting currencies is used. The sequences can cause the document numbers not to be synchronized between the ledger and reporting currencies.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated|Unposted journals from any Oracle subledger that doesn't support reporting currency transfer and import Optionally, revaluation journals
indexed_text: Note: General Ledger enters a document number automatically when you save your journal if:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated|The Sequential Numbering profile option is set to Always Used or Partially Used . Automatic document numbering sequence is defined.
indexed_text: If you use manual numbering, you can enter a unique document number.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated|The Sequential Numbering profile option is set to Always Used or Partially Used . Automatic document numbering sequence is defined.
indexed_text: Revaluation: Run periodically revaluation in your ledger and reporting currencies as necessary to satisfy the accounting regulations of the country in which your organization operates.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated|The Sequential Numbering profile option is set to Always Used or Partially Used . Automatic document numbering sequence is defined.
indexed_text: Account Inquiries: Perform inquires in the reporting currency. You can:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated|Drill down to the journal detail for the reporting currency balance. Drill down to see the source ledger currency journal amounts from any automatically converted journal that was created when the original journal posted.
indexed_text: Note: Be careful when changing amounts in a reporting currency, since the changes aren't reflected in your source ledger. Making journal entry changes to a reporting currency makes it more difficult to reconcile your reporting currency to your source ledger. In general, enter or change your journals in your source ledger, and then allow posting to update the reporting currency.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|How Reporting Currencies Are Calculated|Drill down to the journal detail for the reporting currency balance. Drill down to see the source ledger currency journal amounts from any automatically converted journal that was created when the original journal posted.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Regulation Requirements Example
indexed_text: You have 26 registered companies in Vision Corporation. The regulations require that each company is to maintain a separate ledger. All companies share the same chart of accounts and calendar.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Regulation Requirements Example
indexed_text: You set up a ledger for each company and group them into a ledger set. You can then use the ledger set to perform all accounting activities, while the data remains partition for reporting purpose for each company.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: You have a parent company in one country. You operations in five other countries. Each country has its own legal entity and must report to both the parent company and the local government. All legal entities use the same chart of accounts and calendar. Currency is different and Reporting Currency ledgers have been created. You can group all of the primary and reporting currencies ledgers into one Ledger Set. You can then perform all accounting activities as though you had one worldwide ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Accounting and Reporting Sequences

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Overview of Accounting and Reporting Sequences

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: When you record your journals, you can assign unique sequence numbers. Sequence numbering the journals simplifies the task of tracing the journal entries and is a legal requirement in some countries, especially those in Europe, Asia, and Latin America.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Sequencing enables the fiscal authorities to easily verify the completeness of a company's accounting record.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Sequential numbering of journals enables you to:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Maintain gapless sequence numbers.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Sequentially number subledger journal entries. Generate a sequence number for journal entries created by subledger accounting before transferring them to general ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Sequentially number general ledger journal entries.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Assign sequences within a ledger or legal entity.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Generate reports based on the sequence numbers.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: The two different types of journal sequences used with Oracle Subledger Accounting and Oracle General Ledger journals are:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Accounting Sequences : Gapless sequence numbering for journals which is assigned when the journals are posted or subledger accounting runs.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Reporting Sequences : Gapless and chronological sequence numbering which is assigned to journals when the General Ledger period is closed.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Note: You can sequence journals for ledgers (primary and secondary ledgers) and journal level and subledger level reporting currencies as well as legal entities. If you use journal or subledger level reporting currencies, first define sequences for the source ledger. The sequence number generated for the source ledger isn't automatically assigned to the reporting currency journal. You must then set up accounting and reporting sequences separately for the reporting currencies.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: You can manually define sequences to generate numbers for journal entries. Use the Manage Accounting and Reporting Sequences task to search, create, and update sequences, sequence versions, and sequencing assignments.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: You can also create journal sequences using the Rapid Implementation process. The process creates and assigns the sequences.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Sequences

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Create, update, and search for sequences from the Sequences tab on the Manage Accounting and Reporting Sequences page. To define a sequence, enter a unique sequence name and description. Create at least one sequence version to complete the sequence. The sequence version indicates the series of sequence numbers to be used and the effective date range of the series.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: When you create a sequence version, you specify the:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Effective Start Date: The default date is the current date. The date can be set to any date in the past or future.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Effective End Date: The date when the sequence should be disabled.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Initial Number: A positive integer that's the starting number of the sequence. The number increments by one for each accounting entry.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Note: The Edit Sequences page displays the last sequence number used for each sequence version.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
