indexed_text: Add Exception : When you create an exception, the priority value is always one more than the highest number in the Priority field. Use exceptions to assign different sequences to certain journal sources, journal categories, accounting event types, or accounting entity types. For example, you want to include all journal sources, but assign a different sequence for your Expense journals.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Add Exclusion : Create exclusions to exclude specific journal sources, journal categories, accounting event types, or accounting entity types. For example, you want to exclude journal sources and categories containing management or statistical accounts that don't impact financial results.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: FAQs for Manage Accounting and Reporting Sequences

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: What happens when I enable sequencing in the rapid implementation spreadsheet?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Two sets of defaults are generated: general and country specific. The process applies the general defaults first and the country specific defaults override general defaults. For example, using the predefined defaults, sequencing is enabled at the ledger level.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: For some countries like Spain and Italy, the general defaults are overridden by country defaults and sequences are set at the legal entity level.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Accounting and reporting sequences are generated based on the predefined country defaults. For example, for a France ledger, accounting sequences are generated for each legal entity of the ledger. For an Italian ledger, both accounting and reporting sequences are generated for each legal entity of the ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Journal Approval Rules

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: Create Journal Approval Rules

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example
indexed_text: You can use BPM Worklist to configure journal approval rules.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: For example, you can create journal approval rules that automatically approve a journal batch, or that route the batch for approval based on the ledger and journal amounts.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: This procedure creates the following approval rules:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: When the largest journal amount in a batch is more than 500, and less than 10,000, the batch requires one level of supervisory approval.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: When the largest journal amount is 10,000 or more, two levels of supervisory approval are required.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: If the largest journal amount in a batch is 500 or less, the batch doesn't require approval or it's automatically approved.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Create a Rule That Requires One Level of Supervisory Approval

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. In the Global menu, click the Notifications icon and select More Details . If you're using the news feed default home page layout, then select Show All and click Worklist . 2. Select Financials . The Business Process Management Worklist application page opens. 3. Click your user name and select Administration . You can manage the journal approval rules only if you have administrator access. 4. Click the Task Configuration tab. 5. From the Tasks to be configured pane, select the FinGLJournalApproval task. 6. Click Edit task to create the rules. 7. Click the Assignees tab. The Assignees page shows the participant tree. A participant is a user or set of users in the approval assignment and routing definition. The journal approval task displays three predefined participants. Typically you use only one or two participants, but have the flexibility to add more participants to meet more complex approval requirements. Each participant is associated with one rule set, and a rule set can have one or more approval rules. 8. On the Supervisory Journal Approver participant, click Go to rule . 9. Click the Expand icon on the Manager Approval Rule. That's the default predefined approval rule. If a journal's ledger and source are enabled for approval, the rule is configured to send that journal for one level of approval to the supervisor of the person who submitted the journal for approval. 10. Click the Show Advanced Settings icon. 11. Click in the Active check box to deselect it. When this check box is cleared, the approval routing process doesn't use the rule. 12. Click the Add Rule icon. 13. In the Name field, enter the name of the rule: Between 500 and 10000. 14. Click Expand . Each rule defines the conditions for when the journal batch should be approved and by whom.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Note: The IF component evaluates the journal based on batch, journal, or journal line-level attributes. The THEN component determines who the approval should be routed to.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: 15. In the IF section, click the Left Value icon. The Condition Browser window opens. 16. Click the Expand icon on the Maximum Amount Journal folder. 17. Click the Name attribute, which represents the ledger name. 18. Click OK . The Condition Browser window closes and the attribute name is populated in the Left Value field. 19. In the Right Value field, enter the name of the ledger in quotation marks, for example, enter "Vision Corporation".

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Note: The first condition uses the operator named is . This operator compares the two values.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: 20. Click the Add simple test icon from the list to add another condition.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: 21. Click the Left Value icon. The Condition Browser window opens. 22. Expand the Maximum Journal Amount folder and select the Maximum Accounted Amount Credit attribute. This attribute stores the maximum accounted credit amount across all journals in the batch. 23. Click OK . The Condition Browser window closes. 24. In the second condition, click in the Operator field and select the operator named between . 25. Click the Right Value icon. The Right Operand window opens. 26. In the Operand 1 field, enter the lower limit as 500. 27. In the Operand 2 field, enter the upper limit as 10000. 28. Click OK . The Right Operand window closes. 29. To configure the action to send the journal batch for one level of supervisory approval, click the Add Action icon in the THEN section. 30. Select Add Approver and select Supervisory .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Note: The Supervisory list builder generates the list of approvers by moving up the supervisory hierarchy that's set up in the Human Resources application. Specify the number of approvers, the first approver, and the highest possible approver.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: 31. To route the journal batch for one level of supervisory approval, in the Number of levels field, enter 1. 32. In the Starting Participant field, click Search . The Add Hierarchy Participant window opens and the Get Manager option is selected by default. 33. For this rule, the starting participant or first approver, is going to be the manager of the person who submits the journal batch for approval. In the Reference User field, enter Task . Workflow Submitter . 34. Click OK . The Add Hierarchy Participant window closes. 35. In the Top Participant field, click Search . The Add Hierarchy Participant window opens.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Note: The top participant is the last user in the approval hierarchy. The list builder continues to add users to the approvers list from the supervisory hierarchy of the first approver, until the number of levels is met, or the top participant is reached.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: 36. Click the Get User button. 37. In the Reference User field, enter the sign in name of the top participant within quotation marks. 38. Click OK . The Add Hierarchy Participant window closes. 39. From the Tasks to be configured pane, click Save . The Enter Comments window opens. 40. Click OK . The Enter Comments window closes and a message appears stating that the rule has been saved. 41. Click OK .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Create a Rule That Requires Two Levels of Supervisory Approval

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Create a rule for the same ledger requiring two levels of supervisory approval if the largest journal amount is 10,000 or more. Copy the first rule and make changes for this second rule.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Click the Assignees tab. 2. Select the first rule. 3. Click the list on the Cut icon and select Copy . 4. Click the list on the Cut icon and select Paste . The second rule appears after the first rule. 5. In the Name field for the second rule, enter Greater than 10000. 6. Click Expand . 7. The first condition in the IF section that checks for the ledger, stays the same. Change the operator of the second condition to same or more than . 8. In the Right Value field, enter 10000. 9. In the THEN section, in the Number of levels field, enter 2. 10. Click Collapse . The second approval rule is complete.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Create a Rule That Automatically Approves Journals

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Create the rule that automatically approves journals that are 500 or less for a specific ledger. The rule must also ensure that journal batches for all other ledgers are automatically approved as well.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: CAUTION: It's very important that the rules in a rule set cover all conditions and are collectively exhaustive. If not, errors might occur.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Select the first rule. 2. Click the list on the Cut icon and select Copy . 3. Click the list on the Cut icon and select Paste . The third rule appears after the first rule. 4. Click in the Rule Name field and rename the third rule to Less than 500. 5. Click the Expand icon to open the new rule. 6. Create a condition for journals 500 or less in the specified ledger by first grouping the two existing conditions together. In the IF section, click both conditions to select them. 7. Click the Surround selected tests with parenthesis icon. Both conditions are now enclosed within a set of parentheses. 8. Click in the Operator field of the second condition and select same or less than from the list. The amount automatically changes to 500. 9. Now add another condition to cover all of the other batches that don't have journals for the specified ledger. Click the Add simple test icon. A third condition row is added after the two grouped conditions. 10. Since this new condition is mutually exclusive to the grouped conditions, click the connector to change it from and to or . 11. Click the Left Value icon. The Condition Browser window opens. 12. Expand the Maximum Journal Amount folder and select Name . 13. Click OK . The Condition Browser window closes. 14. Click in the Operator field and select the operator named isn't. 15. In the Right Value field, enter the name of the ledger in quotation marks. 16. Now set up the automatic approval. The Supervisory list builder has two parameters that override the supervisory approval and return a preconfigured approval action. In the THEN section, click in the Auto Action Enabled field, and select True . 17. In the Auto Action field, enter "APPROVE". Include the quotation marks. 18. Collapse the rule. You have now defined three rules that meet the business requirements and are collectively exhaustive. All journal batches satisfy the conditions in at least one of the three rules and are routed for approval accordingly. If a journal batch doesn't satisfy the conditions in at least one rule within a rule set, the rule evaluation process would fail with errors. 19. Deploy the rules so that they can be used. On the Tasks to be configured toolbar, click the Commit Task icon. The Enter Comments window opens. 20. Click OK . The Enter Comments window closes and a message appears stating that the data rule has been saved and committed. 21. Click OK .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: After journal approval is enabled, journal batches being posted are submitted for approval based on these rules.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Considerations for Defining Journal Approval Rules

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Use approval management to define policies that apply to the journal approval workflow.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Rule Definition Consideration

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: One predefined approval rule exists for journal approval. If a journal's ledger and source are enabled for approval, then that journal is sent for one level of approval to the supervisor of the person who submitted the journal for approval. You can configure journal approval rules in the Business Process Management Worklist application. Open the application by selecting the Notifications icon on the home page and clicking More Details or, by using the following in the Setup and Maintenance work area:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Offering: Financials

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Functional Area: Application Extensions

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Task: Manage Task Configurations for Financials

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: For a simple approval scenario, start by defining one or all of the following journal approval rules based on:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: The highest journal line amount per ledger per batch.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: The highest journal amount per ledger per batch.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Your stage in the period close process. For example, are you in the beginning, middle, or end of the month, or in preclose, close, post close, or quarter close process?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: The following table provides an example of rule conditions and approval actions that route a journal approval based on maximum journal line amounts.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Condition Approval Action

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Less than 50,000 USD

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: No approval required

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Between 50,000 and 100,000 USD

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: One level of approval required

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Greater than 100,000 USD

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Two levels of approval required

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: You can build your rules for combinations of ledger, entered amount, approval level, or other scenarios. In addition, you can define rules based on attributes from different parts of your journal, including the ledger, batch, header, or line level. For example, you can use category, source, account, or descriptive flexfield information as selection criteria for journal approval.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Note: To prevent a submitter from approving their own journal batch, select the Skip creator for Approval List check box on the Configuration page in the Worklist application. The approval task is then assigned to other approvers or automatically routed to the manager of the submitter.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Approvals List Builder Considerations

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: List builders are the way approvals management builds the list of approvers required for a transaction based on the rule condition. Each approval rule is associated with a list builder for generating the list of approvers.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: The following table describes the list builders you can use to build a journal approval list.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: List Builder Description

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Supervisory

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Based on the employee supervisory hierarchy, which is defined in HCM. Employees must be set up with appropriate jobs and supervisors. For example, a clerk reports to a manager, who reports to the director.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Job Level

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Based on the job level, which is defined in HCM. Employees must be set up with the appropriate job levels and supervisors. For example, a job level 1 employee, a clerk, reports to a job level 2 employee, a manager, who reports to a job level 4 employee, a director. The approval list is generated based on the starting position specified in the rule and continues until an approver with a sufficient job level is found. The supervisory hierarchy must be defined along with the corresponding job levels.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Position

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Based on the position hierarchy, which is defined in HCM. The position hierarchy must be defined and employees must be assigned the corresponding positions. Use this hierarchy if you need a hierarchy that's different from the supervisory hierarchy, or multiple hierarchies selected based on different attributes.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Approval Group

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Consists of a static predefined set of users configured to act on a task. For example, you can create an approval group called Finance Group, consisting of users from the finance department who must participate in the task approval.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Resource

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Builds the approvers list by using a specific user, enterprise group or application role.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Other Considerations

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Other functionality to consider before defining approval rules.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Both the ledger and journal source must be enabled for the approval process.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: CAUTION: You should not enable journal approval for journals that come from subledgers (with subledger journal sources). Otherwise, if a journal from a subledger isn't approved, the journal can get stuck in the approval process. For any subledger journal sources, approvals for subledger transactions should be done in the subledgers themselves.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Approval is for the entire journal batch, regardless of the attributes used in the approval rules.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: If a journal requires approval, submitting a journal for posting automatically routes the journal for approval before posting.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: A journal can be escalated to an approver by the administrator.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: The task initiator can select Withdraw Approval on the Journals page at any time in the approval process to withdraw journals from the process. Clicking this button enables editing of the journal. After your changes are made, submit the entry for approval again. When a journal is withdrawn, the completion status is set to Incomplete.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Approval notifications display a table of key journal attributes for each journal and a list of past, current, and future approvers.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: The Journals work area displays journals requiring your approval and journals pending approval from others.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: If you're the current approver, the Journals page shows the journals to be approved or rejected.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Allocation journals aren't routed through the approval process.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: You can review the details of the journals and journal lines included in a journal batch on the online and email journal batch approval notifications.

indexed_text: AutoPost Criteria Sets

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Create an AutoPost Criteria Set

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: In this example, you're creating an AutoPost criteria set to post the general ledger journal entries created by journal import for your subledger transactions.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Here's the relevant setup for your Vision Corporation ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: You implemented Oracle General Ledger and the subledgers Oracle Payables and Oracle Receivables.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: You use a non-Oracle subledger called Fast Assets for fixed asset tracking and depreciation.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: You plan to automate posting of general ledger journal batches created by journal import. The automation is to protect the subledger-sourced journal entries from edits or deletion that could cause an out-of-balance situation between the subledgers and general ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Consider these points when creating a criteria set:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Use the All option for category and accounting period to reduce maintenance and ensure that all journal imports are included in the posting process.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Create a criteria set that includes all your subledger sources. Create multiple criteria sets by source only if you must schedule different posting times to balance close activities or reduce processing time.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Define a criteria set that posts journal entries for all ledgers by selecting All in the Ledger or Ledger Set field. When a user submits the AutoPost Journals process, the process posts journal entries for all ledgers in that users assigned data access sets.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: Create the Set

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Go to the following:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: 2. Click Create . 3. Enter this name: All Journal Imported Entries. 4. Enter this description: Posting journals imported from the subledgers. 5. Select Enabled .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: 6. Select the Use Batch Creator as Approval Submitter check box if you require keeping the creator of the journal batch as the user who submitted the batch for approval when the AutoPost Journals process runs. If you don't select this check box, the user running the AutoPost journals process is the submitter for approval. 7. Enter these values and click Add Row to add each new line.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Tip: Schedule the process to run immediately after the Import Journals process to prevent changes to the journals. Run the process during nonpeak times to save resources.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Examples of Manually Running the AutoPost Process

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Create an AutoPost criteria set and schedule the AutoPost Journals process to run on a regular basis following your scheduled journal imports from your subledgers.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: When errors occur that prevent posting of the journal imports, you must correct the errors and manually run the AutoPost process. The following scenarios illustrate the kinds of errors that could occur and how you can resolve these errors.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Scenario

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: The following table lists the errors that prevented journal batches from posting when the scheduled AutoPost Journals process ran.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Error Cause Solution

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Unopened accounting period

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: The journal import was imported into a future period. An error arises when the AutoPost

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Open the period.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Error Cause Solution

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Journals process runs on a schedule because journals can't be posted in a future period.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Invalid or no journals

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Journal import fails to import transactions from the general ledger interface table. The AutoPost Journals process runs on schedule but finds no batches to post. The posting process doesn't run and the AutoPost Execution report shows that no batches matched the criteria.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Correct the error that caused the journal import to fail.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Invalid or no journals

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: No journals were selected based on the posting criteria. Journal batches are available for posting. The posting process doesn't run and the AutoPost Execution report shows that no batches matched the criteria.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Revise the criteria set.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: After you correct the errors:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Manually run the AutoPost Journals process by selecting the Run AutoPost option from the Tasks panel on the journal pages.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Click Generate on the AutoPost criteria set pages.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Verify that the process ran successfully by reviewing the AutoPost Execution report.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: How can I run the AutoPost process?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: FAQs for Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: How can I run the AutoPost process?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: After you define an automatic posting criteria set, run the AutoPost process by clicking the Generate button on the Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets page or the Launch AutoPost link from the Journals task pane.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: The AutoPost process posts the journal batches that meet the criteria defined. Optionally, schedule the AutoPost process for specific automatic posting criteria sets through the Schedule tab in the Schedule Process: Advanced region to run at specific times and submission intervals.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: How can I identify errors that occurred during the AutoPost process?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Review the AutoPost process results on the AutoPost Execution report. This report is automatically created when the process completes successfully. The report contains the batch name, accounting period, and balance type for each posted journal batch.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: The report also lists error statuses for batches that fail to post. The unposted journals with their error status are also displayed on the Requiring Attention tab of the Journals work area and the General Accounting Dashboard.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Note: The Requiring Attention tab also shows journals with rejected approvals.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Why didn't the AutoPost process post journal batches as expected?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Verify that the posting criteria set specifies the precise criteria required to post the wanted journals.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: If the criteria is correct, then verify the following:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Journal imports completed successfully.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Journal Reversals

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: You can reverse journals manually by selecting a reversal action in the user interface, or you can reverse journals automatically by running a process.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Decide which approach is best for journals such as accruals, estimates, errors, temporary adjustments, or reclassifications that require reversal. Reversing journals saves you time and helps prevent data entry errors.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Here are the key areas to understand when reversing journals:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Reversal Settings on Journals

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Manual Journal Reversal

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Journal Reversal Criteria Sets

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Automatic Journal Reversal

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Multiple Countries Example|Offering: Financials Functional Area: General Ledger Task: Manage AutoPost Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Settings on Journals
indexed_text: You can enter and view a journal's reversal settings in the Reversal tab on the Create and Edit Journal pages:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Settings on Journals
indexed_text: Reversal Period: Accounting period for the resulting reversal journal. Required for reversal.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Settings on Journals
indexed_text: Reversal Date: Applicable only to average daily balance ledgers. Accounting date to be applied to the reversed journal, since that's needed for calculating average balances. For ledgers that aren't average daily balance ledgers, default logic is applied to determine the accounting date for the generated reversal.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Settings on Journals
indexed_text: Reversal Method: Method for reversing amounts in the reversal journal. Select from Change Sign or Switch Debit or Credit . The default setting is Switch Debit or Credit . The Change Sign setting means that the reversal puts the original journal amount in the same Debit or Credit column, but with the opposite (negative or positive) sign. The Switch Debit or Credit setting means that the amount is moved to the other column. Required for reversal.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Settings on Journals
indexed_text: Reversal Status: View-only state of the journal reversal. For example, Not reversed or Reversed.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Settings on Journals
indexed_text: You can enter a reversal period and method at any time, even after the journal is posted. If applicable, the following values also display in the Reversal tab:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Settings on Journals
indexed_text: Reversal Journal: If you're reviewing a journal that was reversed, this setting displays the name and link to the reversal journal.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Settings on Journals
indexed_text: Originating Journal: If you're reviewing a reversal journal, this setting displays the name and link for the journal that was reversed.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Manual Journal Reversal
indexed_text: You can manually reverse posted journals that are eligible for reversal on both the Manage Journals and Edit Journal pages. Both pages provide an action to reverse a journal and an action to reverse a batch.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Manual Journal Reversal
indexed_text: On the Edit Journal page, you can select Reverse from the Batch Actions menu to reverse a journal batch, or you can select Reverse from the Journal Actions menu to reverse a specific journal. On the Manage Journals page, you can select rows in the Search Results section and then select the Reverse Batch or Reverse Journal buttons. To select multiple rows at once, use the Shift or Control key. You can reverse multiple journals of the same batch, or of different batches, or reverse entire journal batches that are eligible for reversal, based on the rows you selected.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Manual Journal Reversal
indexed_text: Each reversal journal is created in its own reversal batch and the batch name starts with the word Reverses. When you reverse a batch, a single reversal request is submitted. However, the reversal journal for each journal in the reversed batch is still generated in its own journal batch. Reversal journals for journal-level reporting currencies are grouped into the same reversal batch as the corresponding reversal journal of their associated primary or secondary ledger. Reversal journals for subledger-level reporting currencies are grouped into the same reversal batch as their corresponding primary ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Manual Journal Reversal
indexed_text: Here are some examples of when you might want to use batch reversal.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Manual Journal Reversal
indexed_text: Scenario How It Works

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Manual Journal Reversal
indexed_text: You want to reverse all the journals in a batch that aren't yet reversed, using the same reversal settings. For example, using the same reversal period for ledgers that aren't enabled for average balances, or the same reversal period and date for ledgers that are enabled for average balances. Or, you want to use the same reversal method.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Manual Journal Reversal
indexed_text: When you select the reverse batch action, the Reverse Journal Batch window opens. You provide the reversal period, date, or method. The information you enter overrides any reversal settings at the journal level of journals that aren't yet reversed. All journals eligible for reversal are reversed according to what you specified on the Reverse Journal Batch window.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Manual Journal Reversal
indexed_text: You specified reversal settings for every journal that's not yet reversed in a batch, and you want to process reversals more efficiently using batch reversal.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Manual Journal Reversal
indexed_text: Leave the fields blank on the Reverse Journal Batch window. Each of these journals is reversed according to the journal's reversal settings.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Manual Journal Reversal
indexed_text: You specified reversal settings for some, but not all, of the journals that aren't yet reversed in a batch, and you want to process reversals more efficiently using batch reversal.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Manual Journal Reversal
indexed_text: Use the Manage Journals page to reverse the batch. Leave the fields blank on the Reverse Journal Batch window. Each of these journals is reversed according to the journal's reversal settings.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Manual Journal Reversal
indexed_text: Scenario How It Works

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Manual Journal Reversal
indexed_text: You want to reverse multiple journals from different batches using the reversal settings specified on each journal in these batches.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Manual Journal Reversal
indexed_text: Use the Manage Journals page to select the rows for the batches and then select the reverse batch action. Each journal that's eligible for reversal in these batches is reversed according to the journal's reversal settings.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: To provide default reversal settings to a newly-created journal based on the journal's category, or to also proceed with automatically reversing a posted journal, create a journal reversal criteria set and assign it to a ledger. A journal reversal criteria set contains all journal categories with their corresponding reversal settings and can be shared with any number of ledgers.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Here's how to navigate to the journal reversal criteria set page from the Setup and Maintenance work area:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Offering: Financials

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Functional Area: General Ledger

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Task: Manage Journal Reversal Criteria Sets

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: The Create Journal Reversal Criteria Set page lists all the journal categories with default reversal settings. Find the journal categories that you want to specify reversal criteria for and set the values accordingly. This table describes each reversal setting.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Setting Values Description

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Reversal Period

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: No Default, Same Period, Next Period, Next Nonadjusting Period, Next Day, Same Day

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Accounting period for the resulting reversal journal. The following values apply only to average balance ledgers: Next Day , Same Day . Selecting those values for a ledger that isn't an average balance ledger is the same as selecting the value No Default .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Reversal Date

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: First Day, Next Day, Last Day

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Day of the accounting period when the journal is to be reversed. A reversal date only applies to average balance ledgers. You must specify a reversal date if you select the following values for the reversal period: Next Nonadjusting Period , Next Period , Same Period .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Reversal Method

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Change Sign, Switch Debit or Credit

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Method for reversing amounts in the reversal journal.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Automatic Reversal Option

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: None, Reverse Automatically, Reverse and Post Automatically

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Setting that determines whether a journal is selected for automatic reversal, and whether the reversal journal is posted after it's reversed. Unlike the previous settings in this table, which are propagated directly as attributes in the journal, this setting is used to determine the reversal action that's applied when the automatic reversal process is run.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: After you create the journal reversal criteria set, assign it to one or more of your ledgers. Here's how to navigate to the ledger page in the Setup and Maintenance work area where you can assign the journal reversal criteria set:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Offering: Financials

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Functional Area: General Ledger

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: Task: Specify Ledger Options, with the ledger scope set

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Journal Reversal Criteria Sets
indexed_text: When you create a journal for a ledger with an assigned criteria set, the journal's reversal period and method are populated according to the criteria setting for that journal's category. This applies to journals entered through the user interface and the Create Journal spreadsheet. You can accept the defaulted reversal values or change them at any time, even after the journal is posted.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Automatic Journal Reversal
indexed_text: The automatic reversal process only selects reversible journals whose categories are enabled for automatic reversal in the journal reversal criteria set that's assigned to the ledger. The automatic reversal option for those categories must be set to either Reverse Automatically or Reverse and Post Automatically .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Automatic Journal Reversal
indexed_text: Here's how you can run the automatic reversal process:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Automatic Journal Reversal
indexed_text: Select the Run AutoReverse task from the tasks pane in the Journals work area. The task opens the Scheduled Process page for the AutoReverse Journals process. You might want to run automatic reversals this way for one-time accruals entered in the current period, but tagged to reverse in a later period.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Automatic Journal Reversal
indexed_text: Submit or schedule the AutoReverse Journals process on the Scheduled Processes page.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Automatic Journal Reversal
indexed_text: Enable the ledger option Run AutoReverse After Open Period on the Specify Ledger Options page. When enabled, the automatic reversal process is submitted with the reversal period choice of All.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Automatic Journal Reversal
indexed_text: Note: If you usually reverse journals on the last day of every month, don't enable this option. Instead, schedule the automatic reversal process to run on the last day of the month. The accounting period parameter automatically increments for each subsequent run.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Automatic Journal Reversal
indexed_text: The automatic journal reversal process creates one journal batch for each journal that's reversed. The names for the reversal batch and reversal journal begin with the word Reverses. The process also produces the AutoReverse Execution report, which prints the name of the journal batch that was submitted for reversal, along with the journal batch accounting period. If the automatic reversal option is set to Reverse and Post Automatically , then the report also provides information about the reversal batch.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Automatic Journal Reversal
indexed_text: Note: The AutoPost Journals process that's automatically submitted by the reversal process posts only the reversal journals that it generated, not other journals that are pending posting.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Automatic Journal Reversal
indexed_text: If reversal synchronization is enabled (see the next section for details), the process generates a journal reversal in the corresponding secondary ledger and the AutoReverse Execution report includes information about the journal reversal batch that's generated in the secondary ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Automatic Journal Reversal
indexed_text: After the process completes, you can review the reports for any problems and verify that all journals were processed properly.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Automatic Journal Reversal
indexed_text: Here are some points to consider if you decide to run the automatic reversal process:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Automatic Journal Reversal
indexed_text: If the automatic reversal option on the applicable journal reversal criteria set is set to:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Automatic Journal Reversal|Reverse and Post Automatically and journal approval is enabled, journals posted by the process bypass approval. Reverse Automatically , you must post the reversal journals manually or let the automatic posting process pick them up for posting based on the AutoPost criteria set. Additionally for posting, these reversal journals are considered to be automatically approved if journal approval is enabled.
indexed_text: If you have an average balance ledger, the automatic reversal process doesn't check that the reversal date is a valid business day. However, the journal validation in the journal pages and the import process perform this check and, if necessary, roll the date to the next business day.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: If you have secondary ledgers, it's recommended that you enable the primary ledger option Synchronize Reversals Between Primary and Secondary Ledgers . Reversal synchronization helps to ensure that the secondary ledger remains as an accurate alternate representation of its corresponding primary ledger. If you enable this option, a journal reversal (manual or automatic) in the primary ledger triggers the reversal of the corresponding journal in the associated secondary ledger. If you didn't enable this option, you'd have to actively manage the reversal of journals in the secondary ledger, whether they were replicated from its primary ledger or created directly in the secondary ledger. To set this option for a primary ledger, use the same navigation as you did for assigning the journal reversal criteria set to the ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: Note: Reversal synchronization is relevant only for secondary ledgers with a data conversion level of Journal or Subledger because primary ledger journal replication is applicable only to secondary ledgers at those conversion levels. However, it doesn't apply to subledger-originated journals from Subledger Accounting created by any of the Create Accounting processes, or to journals created as a manual Subledger Accounting journal for secondary ledgers with a Subledger conversion level. Reversals for reporting currencies at a Journal level of conversion for a primary or secondary ledger, and also at a Subledger level for a primary ledger, are automatically synced with their source ledger, regardless of the synchronization option setting.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: Here's how reversal synchronization works with journal approval when you have this setup:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: You enabled journal approval in both the primary and secondary ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: You enabled reversal synchronization between the two ledgers.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: The reversal journal generated in the secondary ledger (for the primary ledger reversal) won't require a separate approval.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: This table shows how journals are reversed in a secondary ledger when synchronization is enabled. Journal reversal depends on how the journals were created in the secondary ledger and on whether a reversal criteria set is assigned to the secondary ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: How was the journal that's going to be reversed created in the secondary ledger?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: Did you assign a journal reversal criteria set to the secondary ledger?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: How's the journal reversed in the secondary ledger?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: The journal was replicated from the primary ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: Yes

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: The journal is reversed automatically when the journal in the primary ledger is reversed. The reversal settings in the primary ledger source

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: Did you assign a journal reversal criteria set to the secondary ledger?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: How's the journal reversed in the secondary ledger?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: journal override any reversal settings on the journal in the secondary ledger that's being reversed.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: Note: Because the journal was replicated from the primary ledger, the journal reversal criteria set has no impact on the reversal.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: The journal was replicated from the primary ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: No

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: The journal is reversed automatically when the journal in the primary ledger is reversed.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: The journal was created directly in the secondary ledger and isn't one of the following:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: A journal for a subledger-level secondary ledger originating from Subledger Accounting and created by any of the Create Accounting processes.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: A journal created as a manual Subledger Accounting journal.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: Yes

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: If the journal category is set for automatic reversal in the secondary ledger's assigned criteria set, you can run the automatic reversal process in the secondary ledger. Otherwise, you must reverse the journal manually.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: The journal was created directly in the secondary ledger and isn't one of the following:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: A journal for a subledger-level secondary ledger originating from Subledger Accounting and created by any of the Create Accounting processes.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: A journal created as a manual Subledger Accounting journal.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: No

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: You must specify reversal information in the journal and manually reverse the journal in the secondary ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: The journal for a subledger-level secondary ledger originated from Subledger Accounting and was created by any of the Create Accounting processes, or was created as a manual Subledger Accounting journal.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: Either Yes or No

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: Reverse the transaction in the originating subledger, or reverse the manual subledger journal directly in Subledger Accounting to ensure data integrity between the subledger, Subledger Accounting and General Ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: Once set, the primary ledger option Synchronize Reversals Between Primary and Secondary Ledgers applies to any secondary ledger of the primary ledger. The option Post Journals Automatically from Source Ledger is set by the individual secondary ledgers of the primary ledger and controls automatic posting of secondary ledger journals (reversals and otherwise), when the corresponding primary ledger journal is posted. To set this option, use this navigation in the Setup and Maintenance work area:

indexed_text: Overview of Clearing Accounts Reconciliation

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: Clearing accounts reconciliation offers automatic and manual methods to group, match, and reconcile related in and out journal lines that no longer contribute to an account's ending balance.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: You can analyze those unreconciled journal lines that are both relevant and responsible for the buildup of the ending balance in a clearing account.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|4 Ledgers|Reversal Synchronization Between a Primary Ledger and Its Secondary Ledgers
indexed_text: The recommended approach for reconciling clearing accounts is to run automatic reconciliation to process the majority of the journal lines, based on your setup. Then use manual reconciliation to resolve the journal lines that weren't reconciled automatically. You can also reverse incorrect reconciliations. Reports are available to help with this process.
