section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components
indexed_text: This example distributes a cost that's recorded in one account to different cost centers, based on the headcount in each cost center.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: The headcount is recorded using the statistical currency, and the cost centers receiving the cost are in a parent cost center. The chart of account consists of the following segments:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Company

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Line of Business

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Account

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Cost Center

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Product

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Intercompany

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Create the Rule

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Navigate to the Calculation Manager, which is the tool for managing allocations.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Navigate to the Journals work area. 2. Click the Tasks icon and select the Create Allocation Rules task. The task opens the Enterprise Performance Management workspace. 3. From the Navigate menu, select Administer , Calculation Manager . 4. Expand the Essbase application. 5. Find the balances cube for the chart of accounts that's associated with the relevant ledger and expand it. 6. Right-click the Rules node and select New from the menu. The New Rule window opens.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Tip: Since the rule is going to allocate cost based on headcount, consider including headcount in the rule name.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: 7. Accept the default values for the rest of the fields and click OK . The New Rule window closes and the Rule Designer opens in a new tab with the name of the rule you just entered.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Define the Point of View

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Set the Point of View to default values that are fixed throughout the allocation rule. For example, if a chart of accounts has a future-use segment that's currently not used, you can use the Point of View to set a default value such as 000. Then you don't have to select a value for this segment when defining the rule.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. In the Rule Palette, select the Point of View object and place it between the beginning and ending components in the flow chart on the Designer area. 2. To have users supply the accounting period when the allocation is run, use a variable. Runtime prompt variables make rules dynamic and reusable. Click in the Value field for the Accounting Period row. 3. Click the Actions icon and select Variable. The Select Variable window opens. 4. Select the Database category, which is the category for the specific cube. The Application category applies to all cubes. 5. In this example, the accounting period is already defined as a variable, so select it and click OK . 6. Click the Member Selector button. The Member Selector window opens. You can set the fixed dimensions namely, Ledger, Company, Line of Business, Product, and Intercompany segments from the Member Selector. You can also set the Currency and Currency type. You can expand the dimensions to find the values or you can search for them. Alternatively, instead of using the Member Selector, you can enter the values manually. 7. Select Ledger from the Dimensions drop-down value. 8. Expand All Ledgers. 9. Select the appropriate ledger. 10. Click the Select icon to move the ledger to the Selections panel. 11. From the Dimensions list, select the Company, the Line of Business, the Product, the Intercompany, and the Currency dimensions, and set them. 12. Select Currency Type from the Dimensions list. 13. Expand the Currency Type node and select Total. This selection indicates that the allocation is going to use balances in the ledger currency, including the equivalent ledger currency balances of foreign currency journals.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Note: If you select Entered, the allocation would only use amounts where the entered currency is the currency that was selected for the Currency dimension.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: 14. Click OK . The Member Selector window closes.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Fixed values have now been set for all of the segments, except the Account and Cost Center segments.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Define the Allocation Component

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. From the Rule Palette, select the Allocation object and place it between the point of view member components in the flow chart on the Designer Area. The Allocate Wizard window opens and the Point of View tab opens.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: This Point of View is specific to the Allocation component, so if you have a rule with multiple Allocation components, you can specify a Point of View for each of them. Since this rule has only one Allocation component, and you have already defined a Point of View, skip this step. 2. Click Next . The Source tab opens.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: The source is the revenue pool to be distributed or allocated. A source can be a referenced account balance or a user-defined amount. For this rule, the source is the communication cost. To retrieve the cost, you must provide the account combination. You already specified values for the Company, Line of Business, Product, and Intercompany segments in the Point of View, so the only source segments to specify here are Account and Cost Center. 3. Click the Member Selector button. The Member Selector window opens.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: a. On the Dimensions list, select Account . b. Click the Search tab and search for the communications cost account.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: c. Select the account and click the Select icon to move the account to the Selections section. d. On the Dimensions list, select Cost Center . e. Click the Search tab and search for the cost center.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: f. Select the cost center and click the Select icon to move the cost center to the Selections section. g. Click OK . The Member Selector window closes. 4. The remaining dimensions, Scenario, Balance Amount, and Amount Type, specify what balance to retrieve from the source account. On the Allocate Wizard window, the default value for the Scenario dimension is Total for Allocations, which is the sum of the actual and allocated amounts. Since the source for this rule only involves actual balances, you must change the value. Click the Member Selector button. The Member Selector window opens.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: a. On the Dimensions list, select Scenario. b. Expand Scenario in the Members tab.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: c. Select Actual and click the Select button to move it to the Selections section.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Note: If you have two rules with the second rule using the allocations resulting from the first rule, use the Allocated scenario for the second rule.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: d. On the Dimensions list, select Balance Amount. e. Expand Balance Amount in the Members tab.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: f. Since the rule is going to allocate communications cost for the period, select Period Activity. Click the Select icon to move it to the Selections section. g. Click OK . The Member Selector window closes. 5. Accept the default value for the Amount Type dimension as Period to Date. 6. Click Next . The Allocation Range tab opens. The range is the spread of values that the source is distributed against. In this rule, the cost is allocated across cost centers. 7. Click in the Select Value field in the Cost Center row.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: 8. Click the Actions icon and select Member. The Select Member window opens.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: a. Select the appropriate parent value and click the Select icon to move it to the Selections section.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Note: Always select a parent value because you have to allocate across a range of values.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: b. Click OK . The Member Selector window closes. 9. Click Next . The Target tab opens. 10. The target receives the allocated amount. Enter the account number within quotation marks in the Account row. 11. Click Next . The Offset tab opens.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: The offset receives the offsetting debit or credit to balance the allocation that was generated. On the Offset tab, enter the account number in the Account row and the cost center in the Cost Center row, within quotation marks.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: CAUTION: The offset must be a child value. If you select a parent value, the allocation rule fails validation.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: 12. Click Next . The Exclude tab opens.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Note: Use the Exclude tab for partial allocations. Specifically where you want to allocate a percentage of the total source and the percentage itself can't be entered. Instead, the percentage has to be calculated based on all the members in the basis and then some members have to be excluded from the allocation target range. For example, a basis contains cost centers 100, 200, 300, and 400. You want to distribute the source evenly across each cost center, so each cost center should be allocated 25% of the source. But you have to exclude cost center 300 from the allocation range. In this example, you would specify cost center 300 in the Exclude tab. When the allocations are generated, 75% of the source is allocated, 25% each to cost centers 100, 200, and 400. The 25% for cost center 300 remains unallocated because cost center 300 is excluded.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: 13. This particular allocation isn't excluding any values, so click Next . The Basis tab opens. 14. On the Basis tab, for the Account dimension, enter the account number that has the headcount values.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Note: The basis determines the ratio in which the source must be allocated to each member of the allocation range. The basis could be distributing the source evenly. Or you can select specific statistical or account balances for a particular period as the basis.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: For this allocation, the ratio is going to be calculated by dividing a cost center's headcount by the total headcount. 15. Enter Period Activity in quotation marks for the Balance Account dimension because the total headcount for each cost center is included in one journal recorded in one period. 16. Enter STAT in quotation marks in the Currency dimension. The values for the other dimensions are derived automatically based on the Point of View and range specified previously. 17. Click Next . The Basis-Options tab opens. 18. Accept the default settings and click Next . The Rounding tab opens. 19. Specify the rounding options in case of rounding differences when the allocation is generated. Since the allocation is in US dollars, on the Rounding tab, enter 2 as the number of decimal places to use. Click Finish . The Allocate Wizard window closes.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Validate the Rule

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Validation is an important and required step. Validation checks for consistency against the outline of the balances cube that it references. For example, validation checks that the offset is a child, not a parent value, and checks that entered values exist.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Click the Validate icon on the toolbar. After the validation is completed, a message appears stating whether the validation was successful. 2. Click OK . 3. Click the Validate and Deploy icon to deploy the rule and make it available for generation in the general ledger. 4. Click Yes to first save the rule. 5. After the deployment is completed, a message appears stating whether the deployment was successful. 6. Click OK .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Generate the Allocation Journal

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Generate the allocation journal using the following steps:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Navigate to the Journals work area. 2. Click the Tasks icon. 3. Select the Generate General Ledger Allocations task. 4. In the Rule or Rule Set field, enter the name of the allocation rule. The Accounting Period prompt should appear. 5. Select the accounting period. 6. The Post Allocations option is selected by default. 7. Click Submit . A confirmation message appears stating that the process was submitted. 8. Click OK .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Review the Journal

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Navigate to the Journals work area 2. Click the Tasks icon. 3. Select the Manage Journals task. 4. Enter the first part of the allocation rule name in the Journal field. 5. Enter a value in the Accounting Period field. 6. Select Allocations in the Source field. 7. Click Search . 8. Click the Journal link to open the journal. The cost that was allocated has a credit and the debits to the different cost centers are based on their headcount.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Now that the rule is defined, all that's needed for future accounting periods is to generate the journals.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Overview of Allocation and Periodic Entries

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: In Oracle Fusion General Ledger, use the Calculation Manager to create allocations and other formula journal templates for generating periodic journal entries automatically. Allocations are defined and generated from preaggregated balances in the GL Balances cubes, which provide the following benefits:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Immediate real-time access to financial balances for allocations and periodic entries.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Accelerated performance for complex allocations.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: You can base formulas on multiple criteria. For example:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Use account balances or statistical amounts to allocate shared revenue or costs across multiple organizational units and ledgers.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Define complex computations based on variables from different charts of accounts.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Group journal formulas together and execute sequentially to update account balances in a step-by-step process.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Overview of Calculation Manager

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Allocation Security

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Overview of Recurring Entries

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Define recurring journal formulas for transactions that you repeat every accounting period, such as accruals, depreciation charges, and allocations. Your formulas can be simple or complex. Each formula can use:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Fixed amounts and account balances, including standard, actual amounts, statistics, and period-to-date or year-to-date balances.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Amounts from the current period, prior period, or same period last year.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Amounts in your formulas, including total balances, entered currency balances, or statistical balances.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: You can quickly create recurring formulas by copying and modifying existing formulas. You can:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Define single ledger or multiple ledger recurring journal formula batches.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Create a recurring journal formula batch that contains recurring journal entries for different ledgers.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Define recurring journal formulas for your ledger currencies, entered currencies, and statistical currency.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Types of Recurring Journals

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Create Recurring Journals

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Schedule Recurring Journals

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Overview of Using Calculation Manger

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: In addition to the Enterprise Performance Management Workspace buttons, the Calculation Manager toolbar displays buttons that are specific to the Calculation Manager. Not all buttons display in all the views and designers within the Calculation Manager.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: The Calculation Manager toolbar consists of the following buttons:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Home: Displays the default start-up option for the content area.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: System View: Displays the main view within the Calculation Manager. (This is the default view).

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: List View: Displays a list of objects that you can filter by application type, application, object or database type, deployment status, and validation status.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Custom View: Displays a view you can change with folders that you create.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Filter Options: Opens the Filter dialog that you can use to filter objects in the List View.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Refresh: Refreshes the view with your latest changes.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: The Calculation Manager toolbar adds the following buttons when you open a rule:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Save: Saves the object with which you are working.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Validate: Validates the object with which you are working.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Validate and Deploy: Validates and deploys the object with which you are working.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Calculation Manager Menus

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: How You Use Flow Charts in Rule Designer

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Calculation Manager Views

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Filter Objects in the List View

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: FAQs for Manage Allocations and Periodic Entries

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: How can I access the Calculation Manager?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Sign in to Oracle General Ledger and navigate to the Journals work area.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: From the Journals work area select the Create Allocation Rules link and automatically log into the Calculation Manager in Workspace to create allocation rules or rule sets.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Note: The application or the balances cube that is currently selected in the General Ledger Data Access Set is automatically selected in the Calculation Manager.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: How can I create a folder in the Custom View?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: In the Custom View, create folders that contain only the allocation rules, allocation rule sets, and formulas you want to view and work with.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: To create a folder in the Custom View :

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. In the System View , select View , Custom View .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: 2. In the Custom View , right-click the Essbase application type, and select New Folder . 3. In New Folder , enter a name for the folder. 4. Click OK .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Tip: You can create nested folders by right-clicking the folder you want to create a folder in and selecting New Folder.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: How can I rename a folder in the Custom View?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Rename the folders you create in the Custom View.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: To rename a folder in the Custom View:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. In the System View , select View , Custom View . 2. In the Custom View , expand the Essbase application type. 3. Right-click the folder you want to rename, and select Rename . 4. In the Rename Folder , enter a new name for the folder. 5. Click OK .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: How can I migrate allocation rules from one environment to another?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: You can export your allocation rules from a source environment and import them to a target environment using a implementation projects. In the Setup and Maintenance work area, create an implementation project that includes only the Manage Allocations and Periodic Entries task.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Then use the Manage Configuration Packages task to export and import the allocation rules.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: How You Use Implementation Projects to Manage Setup

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Setup Data Export and Import Using Implementation Project

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Export Setup Data Using Implementation Project

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Allocation Rules

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Overview of Allocation Rules

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: The Calculation Manager enables you to create, validate, deploy, and administer sophisticated multidimensional allocation rules. An allocation rule is logical expressions or formulas that are created within an application to produce a set of resulting values.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Create an allocation rule set of two or more related rules to launch the rules sequentially.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Before you create a rule or rule set, you must understand the database outline and the application with which you are working. This information helps you create your allocation rules more efficiently. Learn the following about your data:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: How the data is stored and aggregated.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: What level the data gets loaded into the database.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: What order the calculations are performed.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: What key assumptions drive the calculations.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Create allocation rules using components like formulas, member ranges, and variables, including run time prompt variables.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Create an Allocation Rule

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Start Calculation Manager

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Create an Allocation Rule with a Formula Component

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Create an Allocation Rule with an Allocation Component

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Design an Allocation Rule

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Edit an Allocation Rule

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: You can edit the structure of an allocation rule by adding to, removing, or changing its components. You can also edit the properties of the allocation rule's components and the properties of the allocation rule itself.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: You can edit these properties of an allocation rule:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Name and caption

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Description and comments

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Range of dimensions and members

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Variables, you include in the allocation rule

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Scenario

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: To edit an allocation rule:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Navigator > General Accounting: Journals > Create Allocation Rules link. 2. Navigate menu > Administration > Calculation Manager . 3. In the System View , expand the Essbase Application Type , the Application , or Database , and Rules . Do one of these tasks:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: a. Right-click the rule you want to edit, and select Open . b. Select the rule you want to edit, and select File , Open .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: 4. To edit the rule, in the Rule Designer , add new components, and copy and delete existing components, from the rule's flow chart.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Watch video
indexed_text: Note: As you edit components in an allocation rule, you can increase or decrease the size of the component icons and the amount of detail that is displayed in the flow chart. To edit, you use the zoom bar to zoom in and out within the flow chart. When the flow chart is displayed in small or very small sizes, the component captions don't display, but you can place your mouse pointer over any icon to read its caption. Regardless of the size of the components in the flow chart, you can select a component to view its properties on the Properties tab.

indexed_text: 5. To delete a component from the flow chart, select the component, right-click it, and select Remove . 6. Select values for a dimension by clicking its row in the Select Value column. 12. When the Actions icon is displayed, click it, and select one of these:

In the System View , expand the Essbase Application Type , the Application , or Database , and Rules . Select the rule you want to print. 4. Select File , Print .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Names Database Application Name Deployment Status Validation Status Description
indexed_text: Note: You can also select File , Print from within the Rule Designer to print a rule.

indexed_text: 5. In Print Preview , do these tasks: 6. Select the Print options:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Paper size Print orientation: portrait or landscape .
indexed_text: 7. Select General Rule Information to print the rule's description and other details from the Properties tab. The details include the rule's name, the application, its owner, the date the rule was created, and the date the rule was last modified. 8. Select Flow Chart and Expanded or Collapsed , to print the flow chart, and you want to print it with the component details expanded or collapse. 9. Select the number of pages you want to print the components across (horizontally). Select the number of pages to print the components down (vertically). 10. Select the Page Order options:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Select Detail Section to print detailed information about the components in the rule. Select Page break before sections to create a page break between summary, variable, and detail sections. This option is selected by default. Select Nested Rules to print rules contained in other rules.

indexed_text: 1. In the System View , expand the Essbase Application Type , the Application , or Database , and Rules . 2. Right-click the rule you want to save with a different name, and select Open . 3. In the Rule Designer , select File , Save As . 4. In Save As , enter the rule's new name, and select the Application Name . 5. Select the Database .

indexed_text: How can I delete an allocation rule?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: You delete an allocation rule from the System View. You can delete an allocation rule only if it is not used by other rules or rule sets.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: If the rule is being used, you must remove the allocation rule from the rules and rule sets using it, or make copies of it for the rules and rule sets using it, before you delete it. To see if a rule is used by other rules and rule sets, you can show the usages of the rule.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: To delete an allocation rule:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: 1. In the System View , expand the Essbase Application Type , the Application , or Database , and Rules . 2. Make sure the rule you want to delete is not being used by another rule set or rule. 3. Right-click the rule you want to delete, and select Delete . 4. Click OK to confirm deletion of the rule.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: Use the following steps to copy a rule set to another application:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: 1. In the System View , expand the Essbase Application Type and the Application . 2. Expand RuleSets .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: Note: Only one rule set node exists for each application at the same level as the plan types and databases.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: 3. Right-click the allocation rule set you want to copy, and select Copy To . 4. Select the rule set name, select Edit , Copy , open the rule or rule set into which you want to copy it, and select Edit, Paste. 5. In Save As , enter a new name for the allocation rule set, or accept the default name, and select an application and calculation or plan type. Click OK .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: Note: You cannot copy the allocation rule set to more than one application and calculation or plan type.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: The new allocation rule set is added to the application and calculation or plan type that you selected. To see it in the System View , you must refresh the application list. To refresh the application list, click the Refresh icon on the toolbar.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: After you save it, you can deploy, validate, and generate it. You can deploy and validate it in Calculation Manager; you can generate it from Oracle General Ledger.

indexed_text: You can refresh:

indexed_text: By default, when you refresh an application, application type, or database, all of the rules, rule sets, components, and templates belonging to it are refreshed.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .

indexed_text: Note: You can also click the Refresh icon on the toolbar to refresh the entire application list in the System View .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: Note: You can also right-click the application type, the application, or database that contains the allocation rules you want to refresh, and select Refresh .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: You can change the owner of an object such as a rule, rule set, or formula in the System View. The application to which it belongs must be deployed.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: By default, an object's owner is the user that creates it, unless the user changes the ownership. Users can edit only objects they own, except for administrators who can edit any object.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: Scenario

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: 1. In the System View , expand the Essbase Application Type and the Application . 2. To change the ownership of a rule set, expand RuleSets or to change the ownership of a rule, expand the database, and then expand Rules . 3. Right-click the object and select Change Ownership . 4. In Change Owner , select the owner to whom you want to transfer ownership of the object.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: 5. Click OK .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Right-click the rule you want to open, and select Open . Select the rule you want to open, and select File , Open .
indexed_text: Note: The user you assigned ownership to can edit the object.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Generating Allocations and Periodic Entries Manually
indexed_text: 1. From the Navigator, click the Journals link to open the Journals work area. 2. In the task pane of the Journals page, click the Generate Allocations link to open the Submission page. 3. Optionally select one or all of the following options:

indexed_text: 4. Select a rule or rule set from the list of values. 5. Enter the submission parameters, including Ledger , Balancing Segment Value , and Period . indexed_text: Overview of Revaluations

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Generating Allocations and Periodic Entries Manually|Print Output E-mail me the output Notify me when this process ends
indexed_text: The revaluation process is used to adjust account balances denominated in a foreign currency. Revaluation adjustments represent the difference in account balances due to changes in conversion rates between the date of the original journal and the revaluation date.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Generating Allocations and Periodic Entries Manually|Print Output E-mail me the output Notify me when this process ends
indexed_text: These adjustments are posted through journal entries to the underlying account with the offset posted to an unrealized gain or loss account. All debit adjustments are offset against the unrealized gain account and all credit adjustments are offset against the unrealized loss account. If the same account is specified in the Unrealized Gain Account and Unrealized Loss Account fields, the net of the adjustments is derived and posted.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Generating Allocations and Periodic Entries Manually|Print Output E-mail me the output Notify me when this process ends
indexed_text: For balance sheet accounts, the revaluation journal entries are reversed in the next period. AutoReverse can be used to automate the reversals. For income statement accounts that use the PTD method of revaluation, the revaluation journals aren't reversed since each period's revaluation adjustment is for that period.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Generating Allocations and Periodic Entries Manually|Print Output E-mail me the output Notify me when this process ends
indexed_text: In Oracle Fusion General Ledger, the revaluation functionality provides the following advantages:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Generating Allocations and Periodic Entries Manually|Print Output E-mail me the output Notify me when this process ends
indexed_text: Full multicurrency functionality to eliminate currency barriers across a global business.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Generating Allocations and Periodic Entries Manually|Print Output E-mail me the output Notify me when this process ends
indexed_text: Predefined revaluation rules to ensure consistency in generation of revaluation entries each period.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Generating Allocations and Periodic Entries Manually|Print Output E-mail me the output Notify me when this process ends
indexed_text: Usage of prevailing currency normalization accounting standards including:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Generating Allocations and Periodic Entries Manually|US Financial Accounting Standards Board, Financial Accounting Statement No. 52 (FAS 52), Foreign Currency Translation. International Financial Reporting Standards, International Accounting Standard No. 21 (IAS 21), The Effects of Changes in Foreign Exchange Rates.
indexed_text: Support for multiple balancing segments to provide clarity in tracking the profitability and performance for more distinct segments of your enterprise in any currency

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|5 Period Close Components|Generating Allocations and Periodic Entries Manually|US Financial Accounting Standards Board, Financial Accounting Statement No. 52 (FAS 52), Foreign Currency Translation. International Financial Reporting Standards, International Accounting Standard No. 21 (IAS 21), The Effects of Changes in Foreign Exchange Rates.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Overview of Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Oracle Accounting Hub provides the flexibility and control that you need in the implementation, expansion, and maintenance of subledgers.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Configure user-defined subledgers to adopt in a flexible business environment.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Configure accounting rules to meet your corporate and statutory requirements.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Automate to control the processes from transforming source system data to recording of detailed, auditable journal entries.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Use modern reporting tools available in Oracle Cloud to reconcile accounted journal entries. This can lessen the accumulative work required at the end of the accounting period. You can also gain insightful information for your day-to-day business, corporate performance, and to make business decisions.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Oracle Accounting Hub

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: This figure illustrates the Accounting Hub process flow.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: For additional information about Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud, see the Oracle Financials Cloud Accounting Hub Best Practices guide on the Oracle Help Center.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Accounting Transformations

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Accounting transformation refers to the process of converting transactions or activities from source systems into journal entries.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Source systems are typically industry-specific applications that are either purchased from third parties or built internally within the customer organization. Examples of such source systems include: core banking applications, insurance policy administration applications, billing applications, and point of sales applications.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Accounting Transformation Steps

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Complete the steps described in the following table in the order listed to account for transactions coming from different source systems.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: This table contains the steps in the uptake process which include analyze, build, and implement and test.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Implementation Phase Step Number Description

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Analyze

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Analyze transaction flows and activities to determine the transaction life cycle to capture.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Analyze your accounting, management reporting, audit, and reconciliation requirements. Ensure that the source system provides the required attributes to generate this information.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Build

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Register the source system with transaction types and details using the rapid implementation spreadsheet template.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: As a best practice, when performing the source system analysis complete the following:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: 1. Analyze and Identify Transaction Type Life Cycle

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: A source system that generates transactions as part of a business process has potential financial impact requiring creation of accounting entries. As a key step to create accounting entries, these transactions must be distinctly identified as different transaction types.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Examples of transaction types from revenue recognition or billing source systems include:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Complete an invoice.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Record a payment.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Record late charges.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Examples of transaction types from a point of sale source systems include:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Record an order.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Accept a payment.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Receive a payment.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Examples of transaction types from retail loans source systems include:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Loan origination.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Loan interest approval.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Loan interest accrual reversal.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Loan scheduled payment.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Loan late payment.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Loan charge off.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: A transaction type and its associated transaction data typically relate to a single document or transaction. However, the nature of source systems may prevent them from extracting this discrete information and sending it to Accounting Hub for processing. In some cases, summarized transaction type information, such as overall customer activity for the day, is sent for accounting transformation.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: 2. Analyze Accounting, Reporting, Audit, and Reconciliation Requirements for Transaction Types

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Some source systems may already produce accounting entries, while others may produce raw transactions with no associated accounting.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: As part of the analysis, determine how much transformation is required to produce subledger journal entries.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Next, examine the components of the journal entry rule set to determine what rules are required to produce the required subledger journal entries.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: This exercise helps determine which subledger journal entry rule set components to define for source systems data to be transformed into subledger journal entries.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Journal entry rule set components include:

indexed_text: Account rules

indexed_text: Journal line rules

indexed_text: Supporting references

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Such an analysis should, at a minimum, answer the following questions:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Under what conditions are each of the lines in the subledger journal entry created?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: What is the line type, debit or credit, of each subledger journal entry line?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: What description is used for the subledger journal entry?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: How are the accounts derived for the entry?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: What information may be useful for reconciling the subledger journal entry to the source system?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation
indexed_text: Using the example of a loan origination transaction type, determine what are the sources that store the transaction information for a journal entry? Visualize the journal entries that you would like to create for a loan origination transaction type and list all the sources for its transaction information.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|For example, how do you plan to upload fixed and adjustable mortgage rate transactions, as one subledger source system, or as separate subledger source systems?
indexed_text: - One subledger source system consolidates the transaction data upload and reporting view. - Separate subledger source systems enable the use of a unique accounting event class for each source system. With separate source systems, you can configure accounting rules for each accounting event class. For example, you can configure the automatic reversal on accrued subledger journal entries at a specified date or period for a specific accounting event class.

indexed_text: An accounting attribute is a piece of the journal entry. The mapping of sources to accounting attributes specifies how the Create Accounting process gets the value for each piece of the journal entry. For example, the Entered Currency attribute is used to map source values to the entered currency field for subledger journal entry lines.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Add and update source assignments to accounting attribute.
indexed_text: 1. Determine the subledger requirements. For example, how many subledgers are to be created?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Using the same subledger enables you to share subledger accounting rules, and lets you report across all data easily. Using separate subledgers provides more security across applications and less data in each process run providing better performance. Specific benefits are:
indexed_text: - If you run two Create Accounting processes at the same time for different applications, they are much less likely to contend for database resources. 2. Determine what source data is required to create subledger journal entries from transactions. 3. Analyze the transaction life cycles that create accounting impact. 4. Determine how often to upload subledger transaction data into Accounting Hub. This may depend on the immediacy and volumes of accounting requirements in your company.

indexed_text: The Create Accounting process determines whether there is an exchange gain or loss. The process derives the account based on the account rule assigned to the journal line rule with the Gain or Loss side in the journal entry rule set.

indexed_text: The Create Accounting process raises an exception if unable to create exchange gain or loss line for the transaction in these cases:

indexed_text: If the subledger supports foreign currency or cross-currency transactions that may result in exchange gain or loss, Oracle recommends that you perform one of the following:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|If Gain or Loss journal line rules aren't defined and sources haven't been mapped to these accounting attributes If the mapped source doesn't contain any value.
indexed_text: a. Define accounting rules to generate exchange gain or loss lines whenever applicable for the transaction.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|If Gain or Loss journal line rules aren't defined and sources haven't been mapped to these accounting attributes If the mapped source doesn't contain any value.
indexed_text: - Define two journal line rules if you would like to use separate account and accounting class for exchange gain and loss. Journal line rules with side Gain are used for the exchange gain. Journal line rules with the side Loss are used for the exchange loss. Optionally, you can define just one journal line rule with side the Gain or Loss if only one accounting class is used. - Define two account rules to return the exchange gain account and the exchange loss account. Optionally, define just one account rule if the same account is used for both the exchange gain and loss. - Assign the exchange gain or loss journal line rules and appropriate account rule to the journal entry rule set. b. Assign sources to the Exchange Gain Account and Exchange Loss Account. Populate the sources with the account combination ID of the exchange gain or loss account already defined in Oracle General Ledger.

indexed_text: The Create Accounting process groups lines with the same Gain or Loss Reference together when calculating exchange gain or loss. The total of the accounted debit amount and the accounted credit amount are calculated for lines with the same Gain or Loss Reference within a journal entry. Then, the difference between the total of the accounted debit amount and the accounted credit amount is considered the exchange gain or loss amount and the exchange gain or loss line is created if applicable.

indexed_text: Subledgers pass information to the application through transaction object tables. The columns in these tables are named after the source codes. Transaction and reference objects hold transaction information that's useful when creating journal entry rules for accounting. The transaction and reference objects are defined for an accounting event class so that source assignments to accounting event class can be generated using these objects. On the Manage Subledger Application Transaction Objects page, you can view all the transaction objects, primary reference objects, and secondary reference objects associated with the selected event class. You can select the objects to view the details of source mappings. The source assignments display the particulars of the source, its assignment level, and source details.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Y or NULL - Subledger journal will be transferred to GL. N - Subledger journals won't be transferred to GL. indexed_text: Header transaction objects: Header transaction objects store one row with untranslated header source values for each accounting event. The primary key of a header transaction object is the event identifier. You need to provide at least one header transaction object for each accounting event class. All the transaction details that are neither translated nor their values vary by transaction line, or distribution should normally be stored in header transaction objects. Such as the Loan Number for a loan or the Contract Number for a contract.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Y or NULL - Subledger journal will be transferred to GL. N - Subledger journals won't be transferred to GL. The untransferred journal won't appear in the subledger period close exception report, and it won't prevent the GL period close.
indexed_text: Line transaction objects: Line transaction objects are relevant when there are details for the accounting event that vary based upon transaction attributes. For example, a mortgage transaction for loan origination may have multiple amounts, each related to different components of the loan. There may be a loan origination amount, closing cost amounts, and escrow amounts. Each of these amounts could be captured as separate lines, along with an indication of the amount type. Line transaction objects store untranslated line-level source values. There should be one row per distribution, identified by a unique line number. The primary key of a line transaction object is the event identifier and transaction object line number. Transaction details that are neither translated nor their values vary by transaction line or distribution are normally stored in line transaction objects columns, such as the Loan Number for a loan payment.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Y or NULL - Subledger journal will be transferred to GL. N - Subledger journals won't be transferred to GL. The untransferred journal won't appear in the subledger period close exception report, and it won't prevent the GL period close.
indexed_text: Multi-Language Support (MLS) transaction objects: MLS transaction objects are relevant to applications that support the MLS feature. MLS transaction objects store translated source values. There should be one row per accounting event and language. The primary key of a header MLS transaction object is the event identifier and language. The primary key of a line MLS transaction object is the event identifier, transaction object line number, and language. Transaction details that are translated, and whose values don't vary by transaction line or distribution, are normally stored in header MLS transaction object columns. Examples include Loan Terms for a commercial loan. Implementors can avoid having to store source values in header MLS transaction objects by using value sets and lookup types. indexed_text: Reference objects are useful for storing information that's used for creating subledger journal entries. This information may not be directly from the source system or may be used for many entries, thus making it redundant. Use reference objects to share sources' information across applications. For example, store customer attributes, such as the customer class or credit rating in a reference object, and then use it to account for different journal entries in a loan cycle, such as loan origination or interest accrual. Store information, such as bond ratings and terms, and use it to account for entries across the life of bonds, such as interest accruals or bond retirement. Reference objects can either have a direct relationship to transaction objects (primary reference object), or be related to other reference objects (secondary reference object).

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Y or NULL - Subledger journal will be transferred to GL. N - Subledger journals won't be transferred to GL. section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Y or NULL - Subledger journal will be transferred to GL. N - Subledger journals won't be transferred to GL. indexed_text: Sources are a key component for setting up accounting rules. Sources represent transaction and reference information from subledger applications or reference systems. Contextual and reference data of transactions that are set up as sources can be used in accounting rules definitions. Oracle Fusion Applications predefines sources for its subledger. When determining what sources should be available for non-Oracle applications, it's helpful to begin the analysis by considering which information from your systems is accounting in nature. Examples of sources that are accounting in nature include general ledger accounts that are entered on transactions, the currency of a transaction, and transaction amounts. Sources that aren't always required for accounting rules include items that are related to the transaction for other purposes than accounting. Examples of information that may not be specifically for accounting, but which may be useful for creating subledger journal entries, are transaction identification number (loan number, customer number, or billing account number), counter party information, and transaction dates. Provide a rich library of sources from your subledger applications for maximum flexibility when creating definitions for subledger journal entries. Predefined sources are provided as part of the initial data of the application.

indexed_text: If the accounting method has an assigned chart of accounts, it may only be used by ledgers that use the same chart of accounts.

indexed_text: If the accounting method doesn't have an assigned chart of accounts, the accounting method can be assigned to any ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Use the same chart of accounts Are not associated with any chart of accounts|Watch video
indexed_text: Subledger journal entry rule sets provide the definition for generating a complete journal entry for an accounting event.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Use the same chart of accounts Are not associated with any chart of accounts|Watch video
indexed_text: Select the option to define the subledger journal entry rule set for a particular accounting event class or accounting event type.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Use the same chart of accounts Are not associated with any chart of accounts|Watch video
indexed_text: If you're using multiple ledgers to meet divergent and mutually exclusive accounting requirements, you can vary journal entry rule sets by ledger. Each of the subledger journal entry rule sets can meet a specific type of accounting requirements.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Use the same chart of accounts Are not associated with any chart of accounts|Watch video
indexed_text: For example, use US Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) oriented subledger journal entry rule sets for a ledger dedicated to US GAAP reporting. Use French statutory accounting conventions for a ledger dedicated to French statutory reporting. These two sets of definitions have differences based on the setup of the various components that make up their subledger journal entry rule sets.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Use the same chart of accounts Are not associated with any chart of accounts|Watch video
indexed_text: Predefined subledger journal entry rule sets are provided for all Oracle subledgers. If specific requirements aren't met by predefined subledger journal entry rule sets, create a copy of the predefined definitions, rename, and modify the copied definitions and their assignments.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Use the same chart of accounts Are not associated with any chart of accounts|Watch video
indexed_text: Subledger journal entry rule set assignments can be made at two levels, header and line. The following are the subcomponents of a subledger journal entry rule set:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Use the same chart of accounts Are not associated with any chart of accounts|Watch video
indexed_text: You can define multiple subledger journal entry rule sets for an accounting event class or accounting event type. Using the line assignment of the journal entry rule set assigned to the accounting event class or type, a single journal entry is generated per accounting event per ledger.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Use the same chart of accounts Are not associated with any chart of accounts|Watch video
indexed_text: If a description rule is defined with sources, the sources must also be assigned to the accounting event class that's assigned to the journal entry rule set. The description rule may be assigned at either the header or line level of the journal entry or to both levels.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Use the same chart of accounts Are not associated with any chart of accounts|Watch video
indexed_text: Assignment of Journal Line Rules

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Use the same chart of accounts Are not associated with any chart of accounts|Watch video
indexed_text: When assigning the journal line rule, you must identify the line type: Gain, Loss, Gain or Loss, Credit, or Debit. The journal line rule must be assigned to the same accounting event class as the one assigned to the subledger journal entry rule set.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Use the same chart of accounts Are not associated with any chart of accounts|Watch video
indexed_text: When assigning a journal line rule that's enabled for accounting for a business flow, the account combination and certain accounting attribute values are copied from its related journal line having the same business flow class as the current line. Optionally, copy the description rule into the current line instead of assigning a separate description rule.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Use the same chart of accounts Are not associated with any chart of accounts|Watch video
indexed_text: When assigning a journal line rule that's enabled to copy from the corresponding line within the same journal entry, you have the option to copy the account combination, the segment value, or the line description from the corresponding line into the current line.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Use the same chart of accounts Are not associated with any chart of accounts|Watch video
indexed_text: Assignment of Account Rules The account rule assignment defines which accounts are used for the subledger journal line. If the account rule is set up with a chart of accounts, it must have the same chart of accounts as the one assigned to the journal entry rule set. When account rules are defined with sources, the sources must also be assigned to the accounting event class that's assigned the journal entry rule set.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Use the same chart of accounts Are not associated with any chart of accounts|Watch video
indexed_text: There are two types of account rules:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Use the same chart of accounts Are not associated with any chart of accounts|Watch video
indexed_text: Account Combination Rule: Assign an account combination rule to derive the account combination.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Use the same chart of accounts Are not associated with any chart of accounts|Watch video
indexed_text: Segment Rule: Assign a segment rule to derive a specific segment of an account. For example, a cost center or a natural account segment.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|6 Accounting Transformation|Use the same chart of accounts Are not associated with any chart of accounts|Watch video
indexed_text: Assignment of Supporting References Supporting references may be used to capture transaction values on journal entry lines. A supporting reference can be used on a journal entry rule set only if it's assigned a source from the event class of the journal entry rule set.
