section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting
indexed_text: Define a Basic Financial Report Using the Reporting Web Studio

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting
indexed_text: This is the first of six topics on designing a financial report with Financial Reporting Web Studio.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: You can use Financial Reporting Web Studio to design traditional financial report formats such as balance sheets, profit and loss statements, and cash flow reports. You can also design nontraditional reports for financial or analytic data that include text and graphics.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: In this example, you're designing a basic financial report.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. From the Financial Reporting Center work area, select the Tasks panel tab and click Open Workspace for Financial Reports . 2. On the Tools menu, select Launch Financial Reporting Web Studio . 3. On the File menu, select New , Report . 4. On the toolbar, click the Grid icon. Grids are tables that contain data from external database connections. 5. In the design canvas, draw a box to create the grid. The Database Connection Properties dialog box opens.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Tip: When creating a grid, best practice is to leave space in the design canvas for other objects, such as a company logo and report title.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: 6. Select the Data Sources list and select the data source for the chart of accounts that the report is based on. A unique cube exists for each combination of chart of accounts and accounting calendar.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Tip: Best practice is to always turn on suppression in financial reports at the Database Connection Server level. You can verify the setting by highlighting the grid, and then selecting Data Query Optimization Settings on the Task menu. For most reports, best practice is to turn on suppression for the entire grid. Then turn suppression off for columns and rows that must always display. For more information about suppression settings, refer to the Defining Basic Conditional Suppression section in the Financial Reporting Web Studio User's guide.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: 7. Click OK . The Dimension Layout dialog box opens.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Arrange the Dimensions

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Use the Dimension Layout dialog box to arrange the dimensions on your report. For this report, the accounting periods display on the columns and the revenue and expense account information displays on the rows. The company appears on each page and can be selected at runtime.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Drag the Accounting Period dimension to the Columns axis. 2. Drag the Account dimension to the Rows axis. 3. Drag the Company dimension to the Page axis. 4. Click OK to close the Dimension Layout dialog box.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Define the Rows

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Use the Select Members dialog box to define the revenue and expense account rows.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Select the revenue parent account.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: a. Double-click the Account cell. The Select Members dialog box opens with a default member selected. b. Remove the default Account selection from the Selected area by clicking it to select it and then clicking the Remove from Selected icon. c. In the Search field, enter the value for the account that represents total revenue and click the Search icon. d. Select the account from the search results and click OK . The account moves to the Selected area. e. Click OK . The Select Members dialog box closes. 2. Now insert a text row to add space between the revenue and expense accounts.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: a. Select the last row in the grid by clicking the row header. b. On the Insert menu, select Row , then Text . 3. Insert a row for the expense accounts.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: a. Right-click the last row header. b. On the Insert Row menu, select Data . Notice the default value for the new row is the revenue parent account. 4. Select the expense parent accounts.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: a. Double-click the account value in the new expense account row. The Select Members dialog box opens with the revenue parent account selected. b. Remove the revenue parent account selection from the Selected area by clicking to select it and then clicking the Remove from Selected icon. c. In the Available area, expand the Account member, and continue expanding until you find the expense parent accounts for the report.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: d. Select the accounts and click the Add to Selected icon to move them to the Selected area. e. Select the Place selections into separate rows option so each account appears in its own row on the report. f. Click OK . The Select Members dialog box closes.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Save and Preview the Report

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Save the report and leave it open for the next topic, which is adding a formula to a financial report.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Click the Save icon. 2. Select the folder with your name and enter the report name and description. 3. Click Save . 4. Optionally preview the report in HTML or PDF format using the File menu or toolbar.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Add Formulas to a Financial Reporting Report

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: This is the second of six topics on designing a financial report with Financial Reporting Web Studio.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: In this example, you define a formula to summarize the expense account balances on your financial report.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Before you start, do the steps described in the Define a Basic Financial Report Using the Reporting Web Studio topic, then follow these steps.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Right-click the last row header, select Insert Row and select Formula . 2. Click in the empty cell in the new row. 3. In the Heading Row Properties pane, select the Custom Heading option, enter Total Expenses and click the Update icon. The new heading appears in the report. 4. Select the row header for the formula row. The SUM function appears in the design canvas. 5. In the Formula bar, click the Sum ( 0 ) button and enter the formula and cell references in the formula text box. Because the expense rows appear one after the other, you can use the first row number and the last row number with a colon in between. For example, Sum([3:5]). If the rows weren't contiguous, you could put brackets around each row number and separate them with commas. For example, Sum([3], [5], [6]). 6. Validate the formula syntax by clicking the check mark icon in the toolbar. Validation checks the validity of the formula, not if the data is available. 7. Save the report and leave it open for the next topic, which is defining a range function. Optionally preview the report.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Define Range Functions for a Financial Reporting Report

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: This is the third of six topics on designing a financial report with Financial Reporting Web Studio.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: In this example, you define a range function to report across multiple accounting periods. You configure the range to present balances for the last 12 months from the period selected at runtime.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Before you start, do the steps described in these topics.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Define a Basic Financial Report Using the Reporting Web Studio 2. Add Formulas to a Financial Reporting Report Now follow these steps.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Double-click the Accounting Period cell. The Select Members dialog box opens. 2. Remove the default accounting period from the Selected area by clicking it to select it and then clicking the Remove from Selected icon. 3. Click the Functions tab. 4. Select Range from the list. 5. Click the Add to Selected icon. The Range dialog box opens. 6. Define the starting member for the range.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: a. On the Start Member row, click the Lookup Selection icon in the Value column. b. Click the Functions tab.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: c. Select the Relative Member function to define the periods that display on the report relative to the period specified at runtime. d. Click OK . The Relative Member dialog box opens. e. On the Member row, click the Lookup Selection icon in the Value column.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: f. Select Current Point of View for Accounting Period so you can enter the starting period for the report. g. Click OK . h. On the Offset row, enter -11 in the Value field.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: The offset determines the first period of the range. The starting period in the range function is always the oldest period. Because this is a rolling 12 period report, enter -11 to include the 11 periods prior to the period you enter at runtime. The member selection for the End Member parameter determines period 12. i. Click OK . 7. Define the ending member for the range.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: a. On the End Member row, click the Lookup Selection icon in the Value column. b. Select Current Point of View for Accounting Period .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: c. Click OK . d. Click OK to close the Range dialog box. e. Click OK to close the Select Members dialog box. 8. Save the report and leave it open for the next topic, which is defining a grid point of view. Optionally preview the report.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Set User and Grid Points of View for a Financial Reporting Report

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: This is the fourth of six topics on designing a financial report with Financial Reporting Web Studio.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: In this example, you set a user point of view and a grid point of view for a financial report.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: All financial reporting reports have a user point of view and a grid point of view. Best practice is to use a combination of both.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: If you want users to select certain dimension members at runtime, then those dimensions should be set in the user point of view. Selections for user point of view members are global for a user and data source. This means the application saves and applies them to any other report that has the same dimensions set to the user point of view. By default, all dimensions are set to the user point of view and must be selected at runtime. If you want your report to always use certain dimension selections, then select the specific members in the grid point of view.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Note: Members of a grid point of view only display in HTML.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: In this example you set the Ledger, Scenario, Balance Amount and Currency dimensions to use the grid point of view.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Before you start, do the steps described in these topics.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Define a Basic Financial Report Using the Reporting Web Studio 2. Add Formulas to a Financial Reporting Report 3. Define Range Functions for a Financial Reporting Report Now follow these steps.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Select the cell in the grid that represents the intersection of the rows and columns. The Grid Properties pane opens. 2. In the Grid Properties pane, click the Grid Point of View check box. 3. In the design canvas, click the Ledger : User Point of View for Ledger button. The Select Members dialog box opens. 4. Expand the Ledger member and continue to expand until you find the ledger to include on the report. Select the ledger. 5. Click Apply Selection . 6. Select Scenario from the Dimension list to select the type of balance to use on the report. 7. Expand the Scenario member and select Actual . 8. Click Apply Selection . 9. Select Balance Amount from the Dimension list. 10. Expand the Balance Amount member and select Period Activity . 11. Click Apply Selection . 12. Select Currency from the Dimension list. 13. Search for USD . 14. Click OK to accept the search result. 15. Click Apply Selection . 16. Click OK to close the Select Members dialog box. 17. Save the report and leave it open for the next topic, which is setting page and grid properties. Optionally, preview the report.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Work with Grid Point of View Setup and Page Axis for a Financial Reporting Report

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: This is the fifth of six topics on designing a financial report with Financial Reporting Web Studio.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: In this example, you change the grid point of view setup and set the page member selection to a prompt on your financial report.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Before you start, do the tasks described in these topics.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Define a Basic Financial Report Using the Reporting Web Studio 2. Add Formulas to a Financial Reporting Report 3. Define Range Functions for a Financial Reporting Report 4. Set User and Grid Points of View for a Financial Reporting Report Now follow these steps.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Click the first cell in the grid to select all of the rows and columns. 2. Right-click and select Grid Point of View Setup from the list. The Setup Grid Point of View dialog box opens.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: a. To prevent the Balance Amount dimension from being changed at runtime, select the Lock Member Selection option. b. Click OK . The Setup Grid Point of View window closes. 3. In the Grid Properties pane:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: a. Click the Drill Through option to allow drilling from the report to the General Ledger transaction data. b. Click the Suppression section to view the suppression settings.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: c. Enter 0 in the Zero Values field to set the text option for rows with zero values. If necessary, you could also suppress the display of rows with zero values, rows with missing data, and rows with errors. 4. Set a runtime prompt for the Company dimension so you have the flexibility of selecting any company or combination of companies at runtime. In this example, you want to restrict the valid list of companies that can be selected at runtime.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: a. On the grid, click the Pages label. The Company dimension appears in the design canvas. b. Click the Company button. The Select Members dialog box opens.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: c. Remove the default Company selection from the Selected area by clicking it to select it and then clicking the Remove from Selected icon. d. Select Prompt for Company . e. Click the Add to Selected icon to move the selection to the Selected area.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: f. Click OK . The Define Prompts dialog box opens. g. Click the Lookup icon in the Choices List field. The Select Members dialog box opens. h. Remove the default Company selection from the Selected area by clicking it to select it and then clicking the Remove from Selected icon. i. Expand the Company member, and continue expanding until you find and select the default companies you want to display in the prompt. j. Click the Add to Selected icon to move the companies to the Selected area. k. Click OK . The Select Members window closes.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: l. On the Define Prompts dialog box, click in the Member Name field and select Alias . The actual company label displays in the prompt list of values instead of a numeric company value, making the prompt more user-friendly. m. Click OK . The Define Prompts window closes. 5. Click the Pages label on the grid. The Page Properties pane opens.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: a. In the Page Properties pane, select the Alias : Default option so each page of the report shows the name of the company instead of the number.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: 6. Select the four data rows in the grid so all of the rows have the same settings.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: a. In the Heading Row Properties pane, select the Alias : Default option in the Heading Row Properties pane to display the revenue and expense account names instead of the accounts. b. In the Heading Row Properties pane, select the Allow Expansion option so you can expand the parent account values to view the detail child values. 7. Save the report and leave it open for the next topic, which is formatting your financial report and adding a graph. Optionally, preview the report.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Add Formats and Graphs to a Financial Reporting Report

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: This is the sixth and final topic in a series of topics on designing a financial report with Financial Reporting Web Studio.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: In this example, you add formats and graphs to a financial report.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: Before you start, do the steps described in these topics.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. Define a Basic Financial Report Using the Reporting Web Studio 2. Add Formulas to a Financial Reporting Report 3. Define Range Functions for a Financial Reporting Report 4. Set User and Grid Points of View for a Financial Reporting Report 5. Work with Grid Point of View Setup and Page Axis for a Financial Reporting Report Now follow these steps.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: 1. In the report object browser, select the name of the report, which is the first object. 2. Add a logo.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: a. In the report layout, drag the header line to make space for the logo and title. b. In the Header section, click the Add Report Object icon and select Image .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: c. In the Image Properties pane, click Browse and select your company logo. 3. Add a title.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: a. Select the name of the report in the report object browser. b. In the Header section, click the Add Report Object and select Text . As an alternative, you can click the Text icon in the toolbar and draw the text box. The text box opens. c. Enter the report title. d. Select the title text and use the format toolbar to adjust the font size, center the text, and change the font style to bold. 4. Change the page orientation.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: a. Select the name of the report in the report object browser. b. On the File , menu, select Page Setup .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: c. In the Page Setup dialog box, select the Landscape option. d. Click OK . 5. Add a chart.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: a. In the Body section, click the Add Report Object icon and select Chart . b. In the Chart Properties pane, select the Line chart type.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: c. To show only the expense account rows, deselect row 1, and select rows 3, 4, and 5 in the Data Range section. d. Click the Format Chart button. The Format Chart dialog box opens. e. In the Appearance tab, enter the title for the chart. For example, Expenses by Period .

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|11 Financial Reporting|Watch video
indexed_text: f. Click the Legend tab and enter a title for the legend. For example, Type of Expenses . g. Click the Axes tab and enter a title for the Metadata axis. For example, Period . Enter a title for the Primary Axis. For example, Dollars . h. Click the Refresh Chart button to preview the chart on the Format Chart dialog box. i. Click OK . The Format Chart dialog box closes. 6. Save the report and optionally, preview it. For more information about Financial Reporting Web Studio, select the Using EPM with Oracle Financials Cloud link from the All Books for Oracle Financials Cloud page of the Oracle Help Center at https://docs.oracle.com.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Enterprise Scheduler Jobs for Oracle Accounting Hub

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Overview of Managing Job Definitions and Job Sets

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Users run scheduled processes based on jobs to process data and, in some cases, to provide report output.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Each job has a job definition which, for example, determines the parameters that users can set. Jobs are based on Oracle Enterprise Scheduler Services. Using Enterprise Scheduler Jobs tasks, you can define job definitions, list of values sources, and job sets.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Job Definitions : Contain the metadata about the job and the options available to users. A job definition is defined by a job type, such as Oracle Analytics Publisher or PL/SQL Job type or others.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: List of Values Sources : Determine where a list of values for the parameters in a job definition comes from and what the specific values are.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Job Sets : Collections of several jobs in a single process set that the users submit instead of running separate jobs.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: The various Enterprise Scheduler Jobs tasks are:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Manage Enterprise Scheduler Job Definitions and Job Sets for Financial, Supply Chain Management, and Related Applications

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Manage Enterprise Scheduler Job Definitions and Job Sets for Human Capital Management and Related Applications

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Manage Enterprise Scheduler Job Definitions and Job Sets for Customer Relationship Management and Related Applications

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: In the Setup and Maintenance work area, you can find these tasks in the Application Extensions functional area, or, depending on your offering, another functional area. If you don't see the task, make sure that the Enterprise Scheduler Job Definitions and Job Sets feature is enabled at the offering level in the Offerings work area.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Related Topics

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Manage List of Values Sources

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Job Definitions

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub

indexed_text: What are scheduled processes?

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Best Practices for Scheduled Processes in Fusion Applications

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Manage List of Values Sources

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: A list of values source for job definitions determines where a list of values comes from and what the specific values are. Users can select from the list when they set parameters.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: For example, the list of values for a Country parameter gives users a list of countries to choose from. You can create list of values sources to use in job definitions that you or someone else created. Parameters in predefined job definitions can have lists of values too, but not from list of values sources that you can manage. But if you duplicate a predefined job definition, list of values sources might be automatically created for your new job definition. You can manage those sources as you would a source that you created yourself.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Here's how you get started to create, edit, or delete list of values sources:

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: 1. In the Setup and Maintenance work area, go to the Manage Enterprise Scheduler Job Definitions and Job Sets task in the Application Extensions functional area. Or, depending on your offering, you might use a different functional area.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Note: If you don't see the task, make sure that the Enterprise Scheduler Job Definitions and Job Sets feature is enabled at the offering level.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: 2. Click the Manage List of Values Sources tab. If you dont see anything here, that just means you havent created any sources or duplicated any predefined job definitions that would result in automatically creating list of values sources. 3. Go on to create or edit list of values sources.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Create List of Values Source

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Create a source based on predefined view objects or your own SQL query.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: For predefined view objects, contact your help desk to find out if there are any that meet your needs. And to get the view object's full path, which you enter when creating the list of values source.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: For your own SQL query, you can see the Tables and Views guides for more information, if you want to base the list of values source on a specific table or view.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: Your list of values source might behave differently from similar sources used in predefined jobs. There are some limitations to creating custom sources. For example, you cant add new filtering criteria or configure the search.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: 1. On the Manage List of Values Sources tab, click the Create icon. 2. In the Create List of Values Source dialog box, select something from the Application Name list that's related to your list of values. If you don't know what to select or can't find anything that applies, just select Application Toolkit . 3. In the User List of Values Source Name field, enter a name that helps you identify your list of values source. 4. From the LOVType list, select Predefined to use a view object or User Defined to use a SQL query. 5. If you selected Predefined, then in the List of Values Source Definition Name field, enter the full path of the view object that your help desk provided.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub
indexed_text: If you selected User Defined, enter your own SQL in the Query field.

section_id: Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials|12 Extensions for Oracle Accounting Hub|Your query can't have any aggregate function like DISTINCT, SUM, MAX, or AVG in the direct select clause. It can't have UNION, UNION ALL, INTERSECT, or MINUS either. If you absolutely need to use any of those functions, you need to wrap the query in another select clause. Here are a couple examples:

Here are a couple examples:|'NULL' as LookupCode from dual)
indexed_text: 6. Make sure everything looks fine and then click Save and Close . You can't change most of the things about your source after you create it.

indexed_text: When you delete a list of values source, you can't find it and manage it any more, but it's not really gone. Any job definitions using that source can continue using it. So after you delete a source, you can't create another one later with the same name, even though you won't be able to find the deleted one. To avoid confusion, it's recommended that you don't ever delete any list of values source. Just create new ones as needed, with unique names.
